reviews.review: Amazing Tour of Tsukiji and sushi making. Really fantastic tour. We did the private option and had a great experience seeing the market and making sushi. Tour guide was excellent and very accommodating. Highly recommended.

All sushi lovers must get on this workshop!. This market tour and workshop was one of the major highlights from our 2 week stay in Japan. We began with a tour of the outer market, learning about the stalls and buying fish and ingredients for our workshop. Next, we went into the inner market, and all I can call it is a fascinating world of fish!Our last stop was our kitchen to learn about filleting fish, preparing sushi, and tasting our handiwork. Seriously some of the best fish I've ever eaten!We also opted for an extra sake tasting menu, and loved it. The whole workshop was so much fun, and the guys who run it are friendly, funny and so knowledgeable about the market and about what makes delicious sushi.If you love sushi, I wholeheartedly recommend the Tsukiji Sushi Insider Workshop. Go with a healthy appetite, enjoy the fabulous food and soak up the awesome knowledge of your chef and guides :)

Awesome sushi workshop and Tsukiji market tour!!!. We are a family of four with two teenage children, what can I say, we loved it! Fantastic experience. Got to experience the Tsukiji Fish Market! it was amazing and very informative. The Sushi workshop was amazing too we all got right into making Sushi it was very educational. This tour is the full package, if you are looking for a Tsukiji market tour and Sushi workshop this is the one to book, you wont be disappointed. The tour guides and chef are awesome too.

Tsukiji market is an interesting place. We did the auction tour which involved getting to the market at 2.30am for an auction at 6am that lasted about 30 mins. What was worth paying for was the tour guide translating how the market runs and the inner secrets of the market. It also turned out the tour guide helps the security with translation too! The waiting time of 3 hours was spent sitting cramped with other humans like sardines on a hard wooden floor that was in a building next to the market. How ironic! I would recommend wearing pants or shorts and a cushy bum! The auction itself was very interesting and eye opening but we could only see it for about 30 mins. Then the rest of the tour involves walking around the market, visiting some shops. However, it was pretty dangerous as carts drive past you and the people in the market are pretty anti-tourists so it was a big change from the usually friendly Japanese people. The outer market was a lot friendlier tho and we managed to try sake and green tea. Our guide also recommended this amazing sushi restaurant where we had sushi breakfast and were stuffed by 8am. Overall, a great experience but a bit pricey. However, I would still do it again.

If you have any interest in taking a sushi class in Tokyo, this is the one!!. My husband and I did the night-time sushi class and tour. It was amazing!! Some of the freshest fish we have ever had with very knowledgeable people. Our three hours flew by with fun conversation, great fish, and awesome saki.

Fantastic sushi workshop and revealing tour of Tsukiji Fish Market before it opens. We had a great time during this four-and-a-half-hour tour through the Tsukiji Fish Market and the sushi workshop that followed. Getting a glimpse of the fish market while many buyers were still there and before it opened to the general public was a big selling point for me. It was interesting to see that tourists and cameras were not particularly welcome - for obvious reasons. But our guide told us exactly where we could photograph and where not, so thanks for that. Definitely super interesting. The workshop was also great. We could see every step from the live fish to the sushi pieces on our plates. Absolutely delicious and recommended!

Excellent tour . We had Hayashi as our tour guide today and was treated to a very private tour as we were the only booking. Hayashi as our tour guide was excellent. We loved and enjoyed our 2.5hrs with him as he took us to the outside and inside of Tsujuki market. This is a food lovers must do, especially if you love cooking.

100% worth doing. If you like food, sushi or just want to do something truley japanese. This is for you. Very well run and would reccomended to everyone who travels to japan. All my frienda back home were very jealous!

An absolue must when visiting Tokyo. We had such an amazing morning visiting the Tsukiji Market with our guides followed by an incredible sushi making class. We tasted some of the best fish I have ever eaten in my life, learned how to make incredible sushi, and saw the in's and out's of the market from up close encounters with an octopus to learning how to properly cut the fish.

Great Experience . We had the pleasure of meeting Tsubasa Kaieda for the Tsukiji Tour and Sushi Making class. It was fun, interesting and delicious! A MUST-DO for anybody visiting Tokyo! Well done! We were blown away with the first class service!

Excellent . We had the best day at Tsukiji Fish Market up at 6am to get the train from Shinjuku we met with the young guide chef and translator and explored the market which would have been lethal without a guide, we also had samples of cheese and saki from some wonderful vendors and sampled cooked crickets and goodness knows what else. After choosing the fish we needed we went to a little building with three other holiday makers. The chef showed us how to prepare and gut the fish we had chosen prior to making our own sushi fromSea bream, yellow fin,mackerel, tuna, scallops with a selection of saki. Amazing day.

Money well spent. Attending the Tuna Action and Tsukiji Insider tour was a great experience. The tour guide was a bit late which made me nervous but apart from that everything was smooth. If you have the budget, join the tour. The action is very quick, so it was good to have time to explore the market with the guide and no other tourists around. You can see what happens after the action. It's not cheap (100usd), but worth it!

Best way to experience Tsukiji. My wife and I tried to visit Tsukiji market the morning we arrived in Tokyo, and even though we had done a lot of research, we left feeling like we didn't really see or experience what it was all about. Then on our Mt. Fuji hike we met a couple that raved about this tour and said we had to try it, so we booked it the night we got back to Tokyo and we are so happy we did!We did the 8am market tour and sushi making class, and it was fantastic! Going through the market with an experienced guide makes all the difference, and seeing the inner market as we did will be a lifetime memory. The class was super fun, the chef was awesome, the food was phenomenal and every bit of the experience felt like it was catered to our exact wishes. I am so happy that couple recommended this tour, because otherwise we would have left Tokyo without these amazing memories.

Excellent Tour! Amazing Tour Guides. Our family of 5 went on the market tour on our last day in Tokyo! We loved it. The guides gave a great overview of the market and answered all the kids questions. Everyone list this tour as a highlight of our visit to Tokyo.

Excellent!! Must visit before they move to new market!. This was an excellent introduction to the world of TUNA!! It's easy to go to Japan to gorge on sushi and sashimi, but I think you gain another level of appreciation of the food when you know how it is being caught, handled, distributed and finally served on your plate.For the tour, you will need to arrive by 2:30am. I arrived a bit late and was told by security that the quota has been filled and to leave. Luckily the tour guide has good relationship with security and was able to hold my spot. However, it seems I could've lost it if I arrived even later. Around 4pm, one of the buyers will come in to give a run through of what usually happens during the auction. This was an excellent Q&A opportunity with an insider, so be prepared with some good questions.Be careful when walking around because the place is made for business and not for tourists. Bring some cash to buy the fresh goodies at the insider market and for breakfast!! It's a good place to splurge on food because you know it is FRESH!!

Woke up early for the Tuna Auction....worth it!!!!. I had to get up at 2AM for this. Not too bad though since I just arrived from LA. The wait in the room with 120 other people was a little brutal but I just took a quick nap on the ground (bring a plastic bag so you can lay not he ground). I booked their Tuna Auction tour. My guide, Katsuhiko, was awesome. He knows everyone!!!! He got me the best position for the auction and then got me into the inner market and met with a bunch of wholesalers and workers. I really got an insider look at how the fish market works. Also, don't waste time standing in the ridiculous line at Sushi Dai, there are so many other great places to get your sushi fix at the market. Great experience!!!!

One of the best activities in Tokyo. We did this sushi class and tour in Tokyo on our second day and it remained one of the highlights for our whole trip to Japan. My two kids (4 & 8) absolutely loved the whole experience. It was very informative from the beginning tour of the outside fish market, then inside the fish market, and finally the sushi class and tasting. You get to learn about each step of sushi making from how the fish is selected, to what exactly they do to the fish to keep it fresh (a bit gruesome to watch for first-timers), to how a fish is properly cut, and finally how a proper Nigiri is made and eaten. It's more than just sushi making since you get an escorted tour of the inside of the fish market before the general public is allowed to enter. The inside part of the fish market is a bit crazy and quite dangerous with all the trucks and sharp things moving around, I cannot imagine moving through there without a Japanese speaking tour guide. I would encourage people to do this tour soon since the fish market is moving to a new location in October I believe. This is the original location of the fish market and a must see. Overall, this was an awesome experience with the freshest sushi we tasted in all of Japan (even more fresh than the high-end restaurant we ate at called Kyubey)!

Great Experience!. We did the market tour and the tuna auction with Katsuhiko Hayashi. It was an amazing experience and Katsuhiko was a great guide. We arrived at the visitor facility at 230am and weren't excited to wait until 5am for the auction. The wait was worth it! Katsuhiko translated the auction and provided a exciting play-by-play experience. The market has so much history and is really a fish distribution power house. After the auction finished, while the other members of the free fish market tour went on their way, we went on an awesome tour of the market. It was a top-notch VIP experience.

An Exceptional Way to Visit Tsukiji Market. My family of five spent a lovely morning with the team at the Sushi Insider Workshop as part of our visit to Tsukiji Market in Tokyo. For 95% of us who love food and adventure but don't really know how to filet a fish, prepare the basics around sashimi or sushi making or just to intimidated to ask your local, passionate sushi chef, this is a fine adventure. The $150 pp price tag is quite expensive relative to visiting the market on your own. However, given the ability to access several areas of the market before the public (just changed to 10am by the way, effective July 1st), the fact that a skilled, knowledgeable sushi chef with an excellent translator is on hand to talk through his morning purchases, and that you will undoubtedly eat more fresh, exceptional raw fish in a one hour period (the big finish), it is an experience very worthwhile.I found the tour team, led by the young entrepreneurial owner, to be professional, passionate and inviting. Every question found an answer. Every palate was satisfied, even my daughter who HATES raw fish. Long story for another day.The tour team also operates an auction tour and because of their connections throughout the market (I saw lots of access happening with security and other inner market vendors because of their solid relationships), being the very first in line at 3 am is not 100% necessary, if you book the tour company's small group (less than 10 people) visit. Again, I did not attend the auction so I could not give you any insight.But I would give a hearty big thumbs up to Sushi Insider Workshop for a fun filled morning and afternoon making sushi. If you are a michelin starred chef or on The Food Network, this is too basic for you. But for the 95% of us that crave travel adventure but want a little hand holding, this is a very fine tour.

Insider Access... Highly Recommended. Kicked off our recent trip to Tokyo with fish auction tour and sushi workshop. Fresh off the plane only a few hours prior we walked to Tsukiji Fish Market building at 2:00 in the morning to meet up with Katsuhiko by 2:30am. We were informed by Tsubasa a few days prior that the meeting time had been changed from 3:30am to 2:30am because of the increasing numbers of people lining up for tours (Tsubasa does an excellent job communicating and organizing everything and even sends pictures at the end). With reservation we trudged on as visiting the fish market before it moves in November was the primary reason for the trip. To our surprise there were already people in line when we arrived and by 3:18am all 120 slots for the day had been given out.... I should not have doubted them… they certainly know their stuff! They are there everyday, know the market inside and out and are friendly with the vendors. In fact, Katsuhiko personally knows many of the security guards and even helps direct the tourists! He informed us of the best place to stand for the auction and told us what was going on as it was happening. He even took pictures of us, recommended places to eat and most importantly, took us into the inner market around 7:00-7:30am when there was still lots and lots of action going on and introduced us to some of the sellers and dealers. This is the REAL value of the tour! Normally the public (including other advertised tours) don't get access to the inner market until 9am when most of the action has died down. I know this first hand, because for the second part of the tour we signed up for the sushi making workshop and joined up with the rest of our family, getting to enter the market again at 8:30am to buy fish for the workshop and by then it was not quite the same experience… still good… but not AS good.Shopping with Morita san, watching him choose the fish and then having him give a step by step demonstration of the preparation is priceless; we even got to try slicing the fish ourselves. Their set up, located directly in the market place is super convenient. Morita san was very good with the kids and even gave us a few special treats. Making sushi is much harder than it looks but it was a fun and tasty experience with more than enough food. The food was excellent but the company even better. These guys are outstanding and top notch… professional and personable. By the end of the experience they kind of felt like family and I would not hesitate one bit to recommend them to my friends and family!

Great way to end in Tokyo. My sons and I were traveling in Japan for 6 days. Before our trip, I reserved this workshop for 4 people. We arrived at the meeting point, easy to find with signs and two or three people waiting for us. Gathered into a fairly large group of 13, but split into 3 groups so never felt crowded. Short walk to busting inner market. We first get to a vendor (fish monger) where we are shown several of the fish we will be eating a few hours later. They are still alive and then prepared in a style that allows for fresh sushi taste. We then spend time going though the market and seeing an amazing array of fish and sea life. So very sad to see this move in November but so happy to be one of the last to be able to experience this. We make it to the sushi studio, small air conditioned apartment on the third floor of the outer market. There we watch the preparation of nearly a dozen fish for our lunch. Hands on preparation allowed but the sushi master guided the entire way. Fresh wasabi ground by hand on shark skin paddle. Then we learn how to hand roll our own sushi or try sashimi style. Just fantastic. Even if you don't like the people on your tour you really are in your own group so great. Way more food than you can finish or need. The only thing I would suggest is actually LESS fish so as it doesn't go to waste. Great 4 hours and then to Narita back home!

The best way to experience a taste of Japan. Hands down, my favorite experience in Japan was with the Tsukiji Sushi Workshop. My friend and I took the tour in May and learned SO MUCH about Japanese culture and how they prepare their food. It was interesting to walk through the market and learn how to properly pick the right fish (I would've never been able to do this on my own!). After touring the Tuskiji fish market, we went back to a private kitchen to learn how to prepare our fish for sushi. We paid extra to have sake (trust me, it's worth it -- their sake selection is DELICIOUS!) and made a delicious meal with the fish we picked out from the market. Overall, I highly recommend this workshop. I had an amazing time - thank you to our guide and chef for the laughter and great food!

A fun experience. This was a special birthday teat for my husband and he had a great time.The trip through the fish market was bustling and colourful with a lesson in selecting our fresh ingredients.The class itself was well done with great guides and chef instruction.The only disappointment was that they had people attend the wrong day and a couple of extras as well, which made it cramped in the room and harder to see the instruction. As it is a costly activity this was a little frustrating but we did enjoy the experience.

Marking the Fish Market Easy. I bought this tour with two friends and we really enjoyed it. We saw several people just walking the market by themselves, but I'm glad we had a friendly guide. We even made specific requests and our guide worked hard to procure that type of fish. The sushi making was simple but fun. The people were warm and inviting. I feel we got our money's worth. Easy to meet, easy to tour, and a good time.

Disappointing all around, not for real foodies. I am loathe to make criticisms of a business with so many great reviews, but the truth is that my friend and I were truly disappointed at this experience. I am only hoping that my review will save someone the money that I regret spending on this so called 'sushi workshop'. Just to be clear, I am not disputing the customer service, I am unhappy with the fact that it was not what they advertised it to be. On their website, the workshop state "The half-day workshop we at the Tsukiji Sushi Workshop are offering is aimed at people wanting to know not only how to prepare sushi, but everything from learning about the procurement of ingredients to presentation."The tour of the market wasn't bad, it just lacked a lot of vital information. The guide who was perfectly polite, as most Japanese are, didn't give any background or info about the market not even that it's the largest in the world, etc. He did point out some interesting things like sea urchin and fish roe, but if you are into Japanese food I would have though most people know what that looks like anyway. The guide functioned mostly as a translator. The most disappointing part of the so called sushi workshop was that it was entirely about assembling nigiri sushi - we didn't even cook the rice or get to cut the fish. If you already know the basics of how to fillet a fish, then the fish part did not offer much insight either. I notice one reviewer mentioned that the chef showed them how to position themselves at the bench and how to slice the fish but we did not get any of that. We also did not learn how to cook the sushi rice, it was purchased at the market and all we got to do was form the rice and fish into nigiri. A YouTube video could show you how to do that and you could practice yourself for a lot less than US$150. When I asked the guide if he could explain how to make sushi rice, he said that he would email us the recipe IF we wrote a TripAdvisor review. This is blatantly in violation of TripAdvisor's policy on incentivising reviews. If you are a foodie and already know the basics of how to select fresh fish (let's be honest all the fish at this market are fresh) and how to fillet a fish, this workshop is not for you. I truly though the workshop was a waste of money - use the $25 to buy yourself a great sushi lunch and $125 to buy yourself a nice Japanese made knife that you can keep instead.

Wonderful Time!. My boyfriend and I took the class together and had such a splendid time. The sushi class took place in a the most adorable restaurant. Having the place to ourself, we had an great time learning. I wouldn't have wanted to learn how to came sushi any other way. Both the chef and guide were extremely friendly. Highly recommend. A day to remember!

Tuna auction and Tsukiji Guided Tour was a perfect experience. We booked the Tuna auction & Tsukiji Guided Tour and it was one of the best experiences during our trip in Japan. We met very early in the morning with our guide (without him we would have surely missed the auction). Our guide Katsuhiko Hayashi is such a lovely person. He had so much knowledge to share, made us feel comfortable all the time, was so caring and made sure we had a really good experience during this tour. He watched out that we had the best place to see the tuna auction and translated the auction very fast. He ensured that we saw the inner market with all its variety of fresh fish without getting caught in a car accident or overrun by an ambitious customer or seller. He showed us the best restaurants in the market area and even accompanied us to see the outer market. It was a great experience. I can highly recommend this tour. Don’t miss it.

Informational and Fun!. Most first time tourists in Tokyo will make a stop at the Tsukiji Fish Market, but this tour takes that experience a step further. Our group was on the larger side (10 people), so we were split up to better maneuver through the market. We shadowed the chef as he went to his favorite vendors in both the inner and outer markets and made his selections. We learned not only how the market worked, but how to pick the freshest, best tasting fish. A fish monger also showed us how he killed and prepped the fish to be taken home. When we had made all our purchases, we convened at the kitchen where the chef showed us how to make nigiri sushi. Then we were each provided with a good portion of sliced fish and a bowl of sticky sushi rice to make (and eat) our own. It was some of the best sushi I have ever had and I had A LOT of it. The meal finished with a cup of rich fish broth made with the leftover bones. Delicious.All in all, it was a fantastic, informative, interactive tour and I would highly, highly recommend it.
Great fun! Great Food!. Fantastic tour! Fish market, sushi making, the freshest fish! Loved all of it. Great people! Most interesting and fun. Highly recommend.

Awesome time visiting Tsukiji and making sushi!. I highly recommend the morning offering of the sushi workshop because you also get to walk around the Inner Market before the general public is allowed to. The day I did the tour, I was the only one who signed up, so it was like having a private tour. Chef Morita-san and translator Kaieda-san asked what kinds of fish I liked and customized the menu around that – I also told them ‘omakase’ if they saw something that looked good. One of the first things we did was to buy real wasabi root at a stall in the outer market – definitely a good start to the tour. Then we got to see the inner market. We got cherry salmon, first bonito of the season, yellowtail, and flounder (or a fish similar to flounder). Even though I was the only guest, they still bought enough fish for a whole group! I even got to see the special way to butcher one of the live fish that we prepared later.Back at the studio, Morita-san prepared the fish into fillets. At the same time, he created a tasty fish stock with the remaining bones. I tried my hand at some of the sogi-giri cuts to make nigiri sushi – I definitely will need more practice. He also showed how to shape the sushi. There was so much fish, and he also served up some fire-roasted (via blowtorch) slices of the fish. To finish off this great meal, he served up a cup of piping hot fish stock. A great way to experience Tsukiji and sushi!

Highly recommended for foodies & Sushi lovers. I am a Japanese born and brought up in Tokyo. Joined this Sushi Work Shop with my American husband and a friend from the SF Bay Area. All of us are foodies and keen amateurs. We are extremely happy that we made it before Fish market moves to Toyosu location. The lesson starts with the shopping inside the fish market, which is an exciting rare experience as well. You can learn the professional secrets - inherited Japanese knowledge and skills how to deal with the fish. No doubt eye-opening experience even for a Japanese. The hands-on lesson inside the classroom is very well organized. Starting with chef's demonstration, followed by volunteer hands on trial to de-born and slice the fish. We did scallops, too, out of shells. Then all the participants can make your own nigiri on your table. We enjoyed good sake as optional choice. Great choice of sake. Never crappy. Chef Morita-san is very friendly and experienced to share the tips how to position yourself against the counter top and and how to use the Japanese sashimi knife. Hayashi-san and Kaieda-san were very knowledgeable and helpful as well. They also shared the good Sushi place they recommend, which was a big bonus, too. Overall, very valuable experience and so happy we did ! Highly recommended for foodies keen about hands-on lessons, but also never compelling pressures even if you just wish to observe, hands-off and eat Sushi !

LOVED IT!!. It was so interesting going through the fish market. We learned about the different types of fish sold at the market, picked the freshest (as in live!) fish, and learned to make sushi. An unbelievable experience. The guides were great and the sushi chef was great too. Definitely recommend it!!!

Great Organization!. From pre-booking questions all the way through to follow up from the tour, this was a great experience. We were 2 adults, an 8 year old and an 11 year old. Only one in our party actually ate raw fish (my husband), but I wanted to see the market and have our kids experience it as well. We discussed this in advance and they indicated they would have other options available for us to eat. A day or two before the tour, they sent a reminder email with directions for a taxi in Japanese kanji as well as the subway meeting point. This was very appreciated as we got a late start the morning of and ended up hoping a taxi. Unfortunately, despite giving the driver the instructions in Japanese, the taxi dropped us at the wrong location. Panicked we called the numbers provided and they came and found us once we were able to describe our location. Whew!  I thought based on the emails from them that mainly dealt with the tuna auction (we did the sushi making in the morning) that it would be a humongous group. It was not, as there were only 10 in our group, which was a great size and then they broke the group in 2 as we walked through the market. They explained what we were seeing along the way, and walked us through to the inner market. We were there right before the general public could get in, so things had calmed down a bit, but were still crazy busy. It was very interesting to watch the merchants at work, mini forklifts darting all over, preparing seafood, and in general see how it all functioned.  Back at the kitchen area (studio) was where it was really fun, listening to and watching how to prepare a fish, learning about what is in season, learning about Japanese customs surrounding it all, just so interesting. When they noticed our kids didn’t have anything to eat, they ran downstairs and bought both veggies and meat for them. They also ‘cooked’ with a blowtorch some delicious cherry salmon for me to eat. They were very accommodating, fascinating to listen to and the combination of backgrounds of the folks leading our tour gave us what was the highlight of our trip to Japan for my sushi loving husband. Don’t hesitate for a second to book with these guys.

Hands on Sushi Making course. I really loved my experience at the Tsukiji Sushi Workshop (9am-1pm). An English interpreter was present during the whole experience. The chef was really friendly, helpful, respectful, and communicative. I was fortunate in being the only person in this workshop so the tour was catered to my interest. I wanted to eat Uni (Sea Urchin) so they showed me how to pick the best Uni, which was purchased for the sushi making course. They showed me the different grades of tuna and how the fishmonger would prepare the fish. Later, at the workshop, the chef taught me how to use the knife and slice the tuna. I had a guided tour in the outer fish market (where they showed me how to choose the wasabi root) and the inner fish market (where we saw all different types of seafood including puffer fish, which I was interested in seeing alive). Since we had some extra time, the guide showed me how to pray in the Japanese shrine nearby. It was such a wonderful experience - a really important part of the cultural experience! I would do it again and recommend others to attend this workshop.

The ultimate "cooking" class. I've been to several cooking classes but how often do you get to go to the premier market of fish in the world, pick out your products, then make a dish that's world famous for coming from there? It might seem a little pricey, but worth every yen.

Great way to experience Tsukiji and learn about sushi. We had a great time exploring the Tsukiji market with Chef Mori and Kaieda-san our guide. We felt like we had an insider's perspective as we met people working in the market and saw the interaction between Mori-san and his suppliers. Chef Mori guided us every step of the way from electing the many different fish to preparing them to making sushi. It was the best and the most sushi I think we had ever eaten. And it doesn't get any fresher then live to table in minutes. Great family activity if you love food, markets and sushi!

Best meal of our trip!. Although this was our second time in Japan (and Tsukiji) our experience of the market was completely different. We truly felt like locals walking around the market with our wonderful guides who are not only extremely friendly but also a treasure trove of knowledge about not only seafood but also the history of Tsukiji Market. They were also extremely generous with the variety and quantity of food provided, way beyond our expectations. We were lucky to land right at the tail end of the Cherry Salmon season (delicious) and got to taste some amazing Blood Clams and massive Kuruma Shrimp that were so fresh they slapped you in the face when bit. We also had some delicious tuna (from South Carolina) and I believe skate or flounder. Being a rice lover though, the highlight was certainly the delicious rice, cooked just right and seasoned so well I'm unsure I will ever get to taste something of that level again. Do yourself a favour and head over to Tsukiji... It apparently won't be there for long now since it's moving to a new building.

Outstanding Experience in Tokyo. Visiting the fish market and learning the ways of the sushi experience was a highlight of our trip to Japan. Teenagers can be tough to entertain, especially on the tale end of a long trip. The market was buzzing with people and the personalized sushi making workshop allowed the kids hands on experience and plenty of eating. The guides and chef were personable, professional and focused. We will definitely book again when we return to Tokyo.

Wholesome experience. I would definitely recommend the sushi workshop because it has the potential of being a tourist trap but rises above that and instead gives a deep insight on how hard the work of a sushi chef is while giving real cultural insights and genuine fun. Thank you Morita-san and team!

Highlight of our Tokyo trip - must do!. We met our tour guide outside the metro--the other people in our group cancelled so we were lucky enough to get a private tour! He took us on a tour of the inner and outer markets and we picked up different types of fish for later- we got cherry salmon, tuna, seared squid, black clams, and flounder. The market is super interesting and you need a guide for the inner markets, so this was helpful. We took the fish back to the kitchen, in a building in the outer market where the chef met us. He skinned, gutted, and cleaned all of the fish and chopped up a bunch into sushi and let us try when we wanted to -- it is much harder than it looks! We took tons of pictures throughout and were able to taste the sushi while he was preparing it. You even get to grind the wasabi root! After everything is chopped up, we sat down and the chef taught us how to put the sushi pieces together with the rice - also not so easy! We changed off eating sushi and making it and there was plenty of food - I've probably never eaten so much sushi in one sitting and it was the freshest fish I've ever tasted! The chef made a bunch of pieces for us too so that we were able to enjoy it and not spend all our time making it if we wanted his help. Highly recommend!!! Super friendly staff, intimate experience, very professional and fun.

Enjoyable sushi lesson. The session started with the outer and inner market shopping at Tsukiji market. It was a very educational trip when selecting the fresh fish and other seafood from the market. Got to understand the Japanese Ike Jime, the removal of spinal cord to slow down the process of muscle stiffening.The sushi chef Morita san is a good chef and my host Kaieda san is an excellent host!I enjoyed the sushi making process from filleting the fish to the rolling of the sushi in the palm of my hand and finally savoring the fruits of my labor... the freshly made sushi . So delicious .

Excellent Workshop. The tour of the inner market was great, and learning how to cut the sushi from a complete fish to the plate was very interesting. The opportunity to drink sake while doing it is good too, but beware it can result in 'Finger Sushi' being made with sharp knives !.. Great morning out.

Amazing Experience!. We had an excellent time! We toured the Tsukiji Market in the morning and bought the supplies for the Sushi Workshop later in the morning. Don't wear nice shoes since this is a working market. A lot of water and fish guts on the floor. Learned so much about buying seafood and preparing the fish. I have so much more appreciated for the skill involved in making sushi. It's all about the rice! Sake sampling was a great surprise!

Tsukiji Sushi Workshop. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Tokyo. We got clear instructions for the meeting place and met the guide and the sushi chef who spoke excellent English (and translated everything for the chef) and was enthusiastic about teaching and showing the fish market and fish and teaching the fish prep for sushi making.There were only 3 of us in the group so we had a lot of time for questions and exploring the market. An exceptional expericen for not only learning technique, but also about the Japanese culture etiquette and way of lifeThe expertise of the chef was incredible and we ended the session making our own sushi and eating itWould highly recommend

Awesome experience. I went in mid-jan to do the sushi workshop with Tsubasa and Chef, they led us on a quick tour of the Tsukiji inner markets and taught us how to choose good fish. There were many interesting things to see and our guides were very friendly and knowledgeable. The most exciting part was the workshop itself which involved prepping, filleting and slicing the fish before assembling the sashimi. We were also taught how to eat the sushi properly, this added to experience as Tsubasa was passionate about sharing japanese culture with us. Thanks for the great experience!

First Class Experience . My boyfriend and I went to Tokyo in late January and decided to do the Tuna Auction, Fish market and Sushi making tour. We had our own private guide, who was absolutely lovely and ensured that we had the best experience, leading us to the best viewing point of the tuna auction, the best photo points and explaining the entire process to us in well-spoken English. Following the Tuna Auction, we were shown the Fish Market. Most foreigners and individuals who do not work at the Fish Market are not allowed access until 9am. However due to special connections, we were allowed to walk through the market at 6am, with no other tourists there! It was amazing. Following the unique experience, we ran into the talented sashimi chef on his way into the market to buy fresh produce for the sushi making class that would start in an hour. The Chef was funny and interactive and everyone had a go at cutting the sashimi and learning how to slice it in the correct manner. After we did the sashimi slicing, we started making the rice into the special shape needed to be able to sit under the sashimi. It was so much fun and the staff were so attentive and friendly. Not only that, but the other guests on the tour were from America, South Africa, Australia, you name it - this great company is bringing in culturally interested individuals from all over the world. Finally, to make the day even better, there was a Sake buffet! Unlimited Sake, all different types, to drink with the sashimi. It was an extremely memorable experience that my boyfriend and I shared, and we are so so glad we decided to get up early, do the Tuna Auction, see the famous Fish Market and make sushi and sashimi as well as new friends. Thank you so much!!!

Great experience. I booked a combined tour; Tsukiji market and sushi masterclass and have been impressed with all aspects including booking, tour quality and calibre of the ingredients used for the masterclass. I would totally recommend this activity for all foodies visiting Tokyo.

Sushi fun. Tsujiki market has a reputation with their fish ..... So will this workshop.It was great to have Tsubasa and his team (3 of them with chef) show us the interesting spots/ fish. And in English . Our chef showed us how to fillet fish, how they cut fish for sushi n the do s and don'ts with the rice n making of sushi. This together with a extra sake package of unlimited sake made it a fun interaction with others(10 in all ) and of course eating what we made.The guys were professional and the fun 5h went by so quickly!! I would recommend this tour n workshop to learn secrets of their trade

Great fun - really good way to spend half a day in Tokyo.... Great to see the market, and the way it works. The highlight was learning the intricacies of cutting the fish and making the sushi. Tasting all the Sake options was pretty good too!! Brilliant experience. Good fun guys running the show.

Great tour, delicious meal. It would be pretty impossible to see the fish market without a guide. We split up into two groups, each with our own guide, which made navigating through the tight space much easier. The guides were great and were able to answer any questions I had.My favorite part was the sushi workshop right after the tour. We got to try our hand at cutting sushi slices while getting tips from the master sushi chef (it's really difficult). Making and eating as much sushi as you want was terrific!

Tsukiji + sushi making outstanding experience. This is the 1/2 day Sushi Making and Tsukiji Fish Market Morning Tour. Get subway to Tsukiji markets with a guide and get to see the working Intermediate Market after 9am for those that are on holidays & don't want to start at 3am! Great experience being shown market like a local. Then go to a professional kitchen to fillet fish, make different sushi and eat everything you made. Amazing experience with professional chefs to help you, never thought I could do something like this. It was snowing & raining on our day which was OK but have suitable warm & dry boots.

Fun, informative and tasty. Amazing experience to see the Tsukiji market with an experienced guide. Would be very difficult to do well without help. Chef selected our fish then we went to the kitchen to learn how to prepare and cut the fish and then how to make the sushi ourselves. Very friendly team and heaps of amazing fresh fish. Also took us to taste sake and directed us to a Japanese knife store. All around a great morning.

Very authentic. Great way to see the fish market with experienced guides. The size and crowdedness makes the market difficult to navigate if you don't know what you're doing. If you don't speak Japanese even more necessary to be in local hands to experience the market as it's supposed to be. The class after the tour where you select your fish to prepare is also great , and the sushi chef is educational as well as very entertaining. I would have given this an excellent review but the day we went the class was way too crowded for the space. I'd recommend finding a day when you can go with no more than 10 ppl. Outstanding experience otherwise!

MUST DO EXPERIENCE. If you are in Tokyo...whether living or visiting...you have to try this workshop out! It was so informative and provided a welcoming environment to ask questions and truly understand the fish market. They tour you around the inner and outer markets and teach you about selecting fish. Then learning to cut and prepare the fish was only topped by learning how to prepare sushi. Not only do you get to eat the freshest fish but you will not leave hungry! Seriously the best investment of our Tokyo trip. RESERVE NOW!

Inside view with chef and translator.. There were 5 in our group from 14 to 69, everyone enjoyed it! What a treat to have a guide in such an historic place! We enjoyed watching the chef pick seafood for our sushi later in the morning. Would recommend to everyone!

Great sushi class. I had a great time walking in the extremely crowded & bustling Inner Market with Tsubasa and the Chef who are both very friendly and informative. The tour lasted about 1.5-2 hours and we saw many blue fin tunas and saw first hand how they were prepared/sliced with massive knife for sale. There were many varieties of other fishes and seafood! The sushi class was filling and informative and extremely fun! Highly recommended and we got to eat at least 3 kinds of fishes and the yummy tako!! Towards the end, we just kept making more sushi for consumption!! Thoroughly enjoyed my experience and got to meet few interesting people from afar!

Funful experience. Making sushi is not easy! My son loves sushi and he always asks me to find a sushi making class for him to make his own sushi. In the recent trip to Japan, we attended the sushi workshop which was a good activity for the family. The chef demostrated how to peel off the fish scales , cut off the fish head and pulled out the guts. Then, he asked my son to help him to cut the fillets from a fresh fish while it was still moving! It was a really valuable experience for us.

Great way to see the markets . We missed the tuna auction as it wasnt open over the Xmas/new year period. It was great to see the fish market and interesting to see the intricate detail the chef cleans, fillets and prepares the fish. Lunch was delicious. Our kids enjoyed it too (aged 11 & 14)

Sushi lovers and everyone else, come here!. We started with a trip through the fish market and got to taste interesting new foods, and then went into the workshop, learned how fish was gutted and sliced, saw the chef blowtorch queen snapper, and then sat down at the table and learned how to shape the rice, and attach fish to rice, make standing rolls with fish roe, and then finally learning how to hold and eat our delicious creations!! Yum!

Good way to experience sushi making first-hand!. The chef and other translator and guides were friendly and informative, and went through the whole sushi making process with us, from the selection of the fish to the shaping of the sushi! The workshop opened our eyes to the unique way the Japanese kill, prepare, fillet and slice the raw fish, as well as, the various other ways of consuming raw fish other than in the form of sushi! Also learned a few interesting facts such as the reason why the Japanese people usually don't consume raw salmon whereas it has become a commonplace item in many sushi bars in other countries. Definitely worth trying!

Highlight of the Trip. We had a great, well-rounded experience. They (chef and English translator) took us through the fish market and showed us how to choose live, fresh fish, scallops, and wasabi. They also chose tuna and it was the highest grade you can get (when my wife and I returned to San Diego and ate a a nice sushi restaurant, they weren't even offering this grade of tuna on the menu). They lead us to an apartment nearby and showed us how to clean the fish in a way suitable for sushi -- which was much more involved than I was used to and felt more like an autopsy which was really cool and eye-opening. Next, they taught us how to form the nigiri and grind the wasabi. The main focus of the class was on preparing the fish and forming the nigiri -- we did not make the rice or slice the fish which we were perfectly fine with. We were completely full after eating the sushi and half of it was left-over. They neatly packaged the sushi and sent it home with us along with a bottle of the chef's homemade soy sauce! We expressed interest in buying a knife and they took the time afterwards to introduce us to the knife store and owner. We decided not to purchase one but appreciated the gesture. We had a great time and really appreciated the opportunity to interact with these really nice and talented guys!

Highly recommended if you like sushi!. I participated in this tour at the end of October, and it was one of the highlights of my trip to Japan! The tour guides were wonderful, and by the end of the day, I felt like I was having dinner with a group of old friends. I didn't go for the early morning auction, but took the inner market tour and sushi making class. I love to cook, so this was a perfect addition to the tour. The little commercial kitchen and dining room is right off the main road to the market, so it was very convenient. I would do it again!

Unique experience, Excellent Food and Teaching. This is a really great and unique experience. I highly recommend this, and it is a great addition to their tour of the auction. The price for this is also quite reasonable as you will have more than enough to eat to go along with the experience.We were fortunate to have the day to ourselves (2 of us) with the class being taught by a sushi chef and a translator for English speakers. His English is excellent and the two work extremely well together (We had Hirobumi Morita as our chef). The fish are selected based on the types you like, what is fresh in the market, and what the chef finds interesting. We had fatty tuna (better than any I've had in the US), Japanese Barracuda (smaller than most species and delicious), scallop, blood clam, baby sardines...and I think flounder and a snapper variety. At each step, the technique was demonstrated and we were given the opportunity to cut as much as we wanted. The instructions were great and you really have the ability to control how much you work and how much you watch.Rice was brought in from a rice vendor across the street and it was very well prepared. The recipe is provided for that as well. Plating was a fun experience and it really lets you do what you want from single rolls to nigiri to sashimi. The chef even brought out a torch to bring some extra flavor to a few of the pieces and so we could see the difference...a must try on the fatty tuna.This was a really great way to see the sushi process from start to finish, and you really start to appreciate the work that goes into good sushi. The fish you use in the workshop is excellent quality and extremely fresh -- The barracuda are fairly uncommonly used in the class but he was able to find some that were fresher than usual. One of the main reasons I would recommend pairing this with the tuna auction+tour that they offer is that the market is a completely different world once non-vendors are allowed access (workshop fits this time slot). The auction part allowed us to get access beforehand and there was a much larger variety and more activity at that point (6-8am).

Great tour!. Great way to learn about Tsukiji market with a local (so you don't have to pay for a tour of that as well!) and learn sushi making. The tour leaders and sushi chef were extremely pleasant, accomodating and fun to learn from! They even took a couple people to a knife store they recommended to help us buy knives. This course is even more fun if you have skills filleting fish or good kitchen knife skills in advance as you will have the opportunity to do as much cutting of the raw fish as you like!

If you can only do one thing in Tokyo, this is it.. To describe this in one word: Awesome. Chef Morita showed us all around the outer market and the inner markets, offering tips and tricks to fish buying and answering any questions we had. The sushi-making class was informative and interesting. Chef Morita made it look so easy and graceful. If you're a foodie, or just plain love to cook, don't miss out on this!

Authentic, fun, learning experience. We chose this workshop because it included the tour of the fish market with the chef and your guide. We wouldn't have been able to see the fish market otherwise. On top of that we would have been lost in the market by ourselves. We really enjoyed learning how to break down a fish from whole fish to filets. I also really liked eating fresh ginger and grinding my own wasabi - who knew it was a plant?!

Best way to do the fish market. We got a personalized tour of the fish market by a sushi chef. During the tour the guide was buying super fresh fish - mostly live at the time of purchase - halibut, shrimp, etc. We then went back to a room where we learned how to make the sushi. How to form the rice, how to cut the fish, how to make wasabi, etc. Very friendly Was a really fun experience for the family. The team was friendly and the tour was fun.
Great Tour. This tour was one of the highlights of our trip to Tokyo. The tour guide was great and went of his way to make sure we all had a good experience.Would highly recommend.

An amazing experience. I was really looking forward to this market tour and workshop, and it exceeded all my expectations. Our guides were incredibly knowledgeable, telling us how to pick out the best fish for sushi and sashimi. They knew just about everyone in the inner market, and so we got shown a few insider's tips as well. It would have been easy to get lost in the maze of the market, or run over by one of the many carts that were zipping around. Our guides kept us safe by reminding us that it is first and foremost a working environment, and that we should try to stay out of the way of the workers and traders. After touring the inner market and parts of the outer market to buy our lunch ingredients, we headed back to the 'classroom' to make the sushi. Both our chefs were wonderful, showing us the best and most efficient way to prepare the different fish. The group were really fun, and we were all laughing and chatting while we made and ate our sushi.I had been a little bit nervous about attending the class solo, but Tsubasa took the time to speak with everyone both individually and as a group, which helped put me at ease.I would highly recommend this workshop.

Perfect way to experience Tsukiji. This was a great tour to see the market and get a better understanding of all the madness that is happening. We got to learn a lot about what to look for in fish and how the overall market functions. In the kitchen, we really enjoyed learning how to make sushi, all the way from taking the scales off the fish to actually making the nigiri. The amount of food was incredible too, we completely gorged ourselves with sushi. Could not recommend this enough, a great experience.

Absolute fun! You HAVE to do this while in Tokyo!. In a short word: AWESOME. Tsubasa and Morita made the whole experience a real blast. The workshop taught my wife and I a lot of about the craftsmanship that goes into sushi making. The guides, Tsubasa and Morita, were very gracious in helping us foreigners learn about their culture and craft. Morita was obviously very skilled in picking out his fish and in his preparation of fish.There was a LOT to take in but it was fascinating to learn the differences in seasonal fish, how to find the right ones, and how to prepare each one for sushi. We should have brought a camcorder!We mainly learned to make nigiri so if you're looking to make something like California rolls or other Western rolls like that, this is not the right place. This workshop is all about Japanese style sushi so it's good to keep an open mind and palate.The best part about the whole thing is that we got to know our guides, Tsubasa and Morita really well that it felt like we were leaving our friends behind when the class was over. If you ever get a chance, ask Morita about the one time he almost died from eating pufferfish. It is a fantastic story!

Amazing Fun. A must do in Tokyo it was great fun! Best tour of the fish market and learning how to cut and make sushi in TOKYO was a super cool experience. You cant do this in many cities so highly recommend to take the opportunity when you're there!

Amazing. Please book this tour in advance! Its great to get specialist comments and guidelines at Tsukiji tuna auction. We had amazing experience with Tsukiji team, watched the tuna auction from the best spot, at the right time, our Tsukiji guide was very knowledgable about the auction and told us many interesting facts about it and Japan overall. After we had great tour around and saw fish market pre-opening. We defo recommend taking this tour, other participants around were a bit lost on whats going on and what to do- what to watch..but not us. At the end we had great breakfast at very local place with no crowds and delicious Japanese cuisine. Our guide took care of us from the beginning till the end of the experience - when heavy rain started he made everything possible to get as a cab asap and get safely back to our hotel.

Adored it, a real highlight. What a fantastic experience this was. We saw other tourists looking lost, confused and getting in the way in the market but with the guys from the Tsukiji workshop we felt like locals being expertly guided around the market. We gained a fascinating insight from our sushi master in everything the market had to offer for an hour or so before heading to the small classroom in the market to watch, learn and make our own sushi. A really fantastic experience that I could not recommend enough. It felt personal, it felt real and it gave us wonderful memories.. and an amazing lunch!

So much fun, well worth the price!. I am a chef in the states and I loved this class. Walking around the fish market with the sushi chef is fantastic he knows everyone and explains things well. after going through the market and buying all the fresh fish we headed back to his kitchen located in the market area. He expertly cut up the fish and allowed anyone who wanted to, to practice cutting up whole fish. We made a variety of nagiri and roasted scallops in the shell. Both the teacher and interpreter we very nice and happy to answer all of my many questions. Highly recommended!! I've been traveling the world for 4 months taking cooking classes everywhere and this is one of the better i've done.

Must do in Tokyo, friendly and experienced operators, great fun!. My girlfriend and I took part in the Tsukiji Market Tour & the Sushi making workshop in mid October 2015. Being sushi lovers from Australia, we read the reviews on trip advisor and heard stories about this unique tour. It was fantastic and the guides Tsubasa and Sushi expert Hirobumi showed us an awesome day, with quality english interpretation and throwing in the odd joke or two. We begun by being guided through the marketplaces, both the outer and the inner market, and learning about the local produce, meeting different vendors and gaining an understanding of the area and its purpose. Once inside the main market we were able to learn about the seasonal fish and seafood, handling and the art behind picking the right one. After all of this, you take the produce back to the kitchen and the fun begins, sushi making! Even for us rookies, we seemed to get a hold of it pretty quickly. Slicing the fish was heaps of fun and I highly recommend this if your visiting Tokyo. Thanks for an awesome day.

Fantastic day. Tsukiji Sushi workshop was a fantastic day. Tsubasasan ensured that we saw and understood the process of buying and preparing fish for sushi - and most importantly - the rice! They were fantastic. All in all a perfect introduction to Japan. Thank you so much.

Great experience, must do while you are in Tokyo. The visit of the Tsukiji market is just amazing. Be prepared to see all kind of fish and see fruit. The explanations to choose the fish are clear and very useful.During the sushi workshop, you'll learn how to clean and cut the fish you have just bought minutes before. Don't hesitate to practice the skin removal and the cut of sashimis yourself, I still have all my fingers left .Finally making the sushis and eating them is just the icing on top of the cake.

Great time!. Tsubasa-san and Morita-san's crew were very friendly and you could have as much hands-on as you're comfortable with throughout the workshop. I booked the wrong day but Tsubasa-san was happy to accommodate the change!

Fun filled morning at Tsukiji!. We had a great morning with Tsubasa and Morata-San, first exploring the outer and inner market while buying various fresh fish and, wasabi and then preparing everything in their studio. Morata-San took great care in selecting the fish and explaining what to look for. We had a nice lesson on how to clean and cut whole fish and each of us could practice which was nice. We probably overbought and thus had a bit too much time preparing the meal but then that's a good problem to have! Tsubasa was generous with his time, taking us after to shop in the market for a sushi knife and get a detailed explanation for how to make the sushi rice.And also of importance...the sushi we prepared was fantastic!

Morita-san's knowledge was the highlight for me and our language barrier was not a barrier at all!!!. Morita-san's knowledge of the fish market and the people who worked there was awesome to watch. He knew his way around the maze of stall holders within the market and was always concerned with our safety and told us exactly what to look for when selecting ingredients for the making of sushi. There was an interpreter there for us but I believe that it was not always needed and Morita-san understood more English than he could actually speak.

Had a fantastic class. We just came back from Tokyo and they had accommodated a last minute booking e had that week. It was just my husband and i that did the class. Both Tsubasa and Chef Morita were great. They were very informative and it was a fun class. They were also hands on and they had made us do everything as well. One you shouldn't miss especially if you love to cook and entertain. Highly recommended.

Take the tour with Tsubasa and his guides! Fantastic!. We took a chance by booking this tour from the U.S. Glad we did. Tsubasa Texted us the day before the tour which eased our minds. We arranged for a cab to get us to Tsukiji by 3:30 am. Everything worked out. There were about 8 of us signed up so Tsubasa split us into 2 groups - our guide Hiyasi (sp?) was knowledgeable and spoke very good English. The 2 hour wait passed quickly. After the auction they took us to places tourists do not have access. Worth the money. Hiyasi "thank you for picking the sushi restaurant - excellent!"

Awesome, Knowledgable. At 1st, you think you may have overpaid while others waiting with you are there for free. After you get in, it all changes. Tsubasa translates pricing and tells you exactly what's going on. Mr. Morita who has worked there for 10 years also provides much detail. Then we go through the "Inner" market where only restaurants owners and chefs get to go. Because of Mr. Morita and Tsubasa, we were able to go through the market and view all the different types of fish. It was a great experience. They were both nice enough to spend more time with us as we strolled through the outer market. Well worth it.

A unique sushi making experience!. This was the highlight of our trip to Japan. The workshop is like what other reviewers have described, so I'm not going to go into the generals. What was really unique was that we picked what was fresh from the market that day. We had scallops, squid, mackerel, flounder, and of course... tuna! We learned to prepare each of them step by step, which is actually not something that they teach you in a typical sushi making class. I also liked making real wasabi. The chef and tour guide are open to any and every type of question, which made it all the more fun.

Fantastic experience for sushi lovers. This 4 hour workshop was awesome. We started with a walk through the Tsukiji Fish Market selecting our produce. Mori-san and Tsuba-san were very knowledgeable. We then went to the workshop where chef Mori-san walked us through a variety of techniques including deboning small fish, slicing sashimi and making sushi. Loved it!

If you love sushi and unique experiences, then this is a MUST do!. We met our guides at the train station exit with a small group and headed to the market. We were amazed at the surroundings and the massive market. Morita our sushi expert taught us how to chose fresh seafood and we watched as he picked our fare for the day. After stopping for fresh steamed sticky rice, and learning how to choose wasabi, we headed to the kitchen. The work environment was clean and comfortable. Morita demonstrated cleaning large scallops then allowed us each a try for personal practice. This continued with filleting of mackerel, flathead and the prize...beautiful tuna! We prepared our wasabi and then sat around the table ready to make sushi. Again Morita showed us how to form the rice, place the wasabi and top with the freshly prepared ingredients. Beautiful sashimi! We all ate our fare until we could eat no more. The English speaking guides made this easy and the experience made our trip to Japan. I highly recommend you to take this tour, it's worth every dollar. Expect 4 1/2 hours of food education, fun, laughter and great food!

Great private tour of the market as well as good instructions in making Sushi. Even though it was raining, we were still able to do a tour of the market. Tsubasa was our interpreter and Chef Morita took us around the market. Both are extremely knowledgeable about the seafood in the market. They have an extensive network, and was able to get many fresh fishes. We were able to pick up fresh Aji, which is extremely hard to do. They taught us how to pick out good fishes, and many other great techniques. Back at the lab, they showed us how to debone and clean a fish, then slice it up. The meal was wonderful and lively. Our group of 4 really enjoyed the event, and it was one of the major highlights of our trip.There was so much food too. We left stuffed to the brim with wonderful food. I would love to have another meal with them in the future.

Tuna Auction & Tsukiji Guided Tour. We met Mr. Kaieda and Mr. Morita at 3:15 am tone among the 120 tourists and guides to be allowed to enter and view the Tsukiji fish market (Tokyo) tuna auction, followed by a guided tour of the expansive Tsukiji market. Our guides were friendly, knowledgeable, courteous and spoke excellent English. They were clearly in the know, navigating the stalls and describing the many aspects of the fresh fish trade before the tourist crowds filled the place. After the tour, they pointed out some great local restaurants for sushi!

Expert instruction. This workshop was great. I have toured Tsukiji several times, but touring it with a professional was obviously a much more educational experience. I have also taken a sushi making class before, but this class focused on the cutting of the fish, which is, for me, the more difficult aspect of the process since it is something that one hesitates to practice at home. I will definitely take this class again when I next go to Tokyo. I have already recommended it to several friends. I would recommend this to both those who never cook and to those who are experienced home cooks.If you like to take photos, then definitely bring your camera. There are a lot of things you will want to photograph, both at the market and during the workshop. Wear sneakers. Don't wear sandals or shoes that you would not want to get a little messy from walking around a place where there is a lot of water on the ground and that water may have a little runoff from cutting up fish.

Something for both the casual tourist and the intrepid home cook!. This was an eye opening foray into the exclusive world of Japan's art of sushi making. If you ever wondered what goes on before that exquisite piece of nigiri sushi ends up on your geta during an omakase meal, this is a must do on your agenda for Tokyo. The Tsukiji fish market needs no introduction, but navigating the labyrinthean innards of the wholesale section is made that much easier with good guides Morita-san and Tsubasa-san. Of course, being the consummate foodie and aspiring home cook myself, I got a chance to pick and choose which seafood items we wanted for our sushi making experience, then followed the experts as we hunted down our assortment of live and live finished catch of the day. Learning how to shuck, clean and process the seafood for the day was very informative and instructional with experienced chef Morita-san. For the class that day, we ended up with hirame, suzuki, akagai, kaki, otoro and akami. During the process, the more squeamish were content to watch the live entertainment as scaling, filleting, skinning, cleaning and slicing went on. However, the organizers are very welcoming to participants, and for those with an interest in the culinary arts, this is where you get more than your money's worth. All in all, I highly recommend this for anyone with an interest in cooking, even if you're not going to run off and host sushi parties. Just the skill sets of choosing and processing seafood would be a great takeaway from this class. For those who want an informative guide and an authentic local experience, this fares pretty well too!

Informative and fun. Access to another world and then Sushi making lessons and eating. It will take a few hours and starts early so be well rested but it's definitely worth the trip for foodies and for those willing to explore new and learn Japanese culinary life. Great host

Why did I wait until the last minute?. We were so lucky that Tsubasa and Mr. Marito made time for us during our trip! I waited right up until the last minute to make arrangements for this very original tour of the Tokyo fish market, and I don't know why I waited. However, we didn't get to go to the actual market that happens in the mornings. Our wonderful guides took us through while it was quiet and explained it all and we didn't feel like we were in anyone's way, so it worked out just as well.Afterwards we went to the workshop and learned how to scale and fillet fish we wanted to make into sushi - which we did. We had a great time and the sushi was excellent. Tsubasa-san and Morito-san both went out of their way to make sure our trip with them was memorable. Thanks to both of them!

Very nice experience though missed the live tuna auction, lively hood of the entire market, many visitors from all over. energy, variety of products, load of stuff moved in such a short time, many more to absorb. A bit too crowded, but they work hard and no time to waste.

If you love Sushi you must do this. This was a great tour The guide spoke perfect English He was very knowledgeable about the facts of the market and gave us a great insight on how it operates and the history. The best part was having the sushi chief with us during the tour to help pick our fish before going to the sushi making workshop. The workshop was very clean and professionally run. It was a 2 min walk from the outer market. I recommend that you stop and buy some cold beers to enjoy you amazing sushi lunch. Don't forget to buy a beer for the Sushi chief.

An experience like no other. This was such an amazing experience! I booked both the Tuna Auction and Sushi Workshop for me and my mom, so it was a long day starting at 3:30 am, but a one-of-a-kind, must do activity if you are ever in Tokyo. It was great to have Tsubasa as our guide and translator throughout the day. This was one of the most memorable experiences I had in our entire trip to Japan. Thank you Tsukiji Sushi Workshop!

Seeing Tsukiji WIth The Sushi Chefs! A+. We had a fantastic time at the Tsukiji Sushi Making workshop with Tsubasa, Mr Morita and Mr Mori (our hosts).There are several aspects of the tour that are truly unique, making it a great experience for my wife and I to attend. These included:- getting a tour of the fish market with a local expert, so that the subtleties of how the fish market operates, the types of fish and ways to select fish, can be pointed out- going with a regular tour also affords unique times to take photos (eg. if I had gone without a tour, I wouldn't have had the chance to take the photos I did....as the tour stops at specific stores and gets nice and close)- seeing how fresh fish is prepared when sold for the purpose of sushi/sashimiAnd then at the cooking class after the tour...- seeing how sushi chefs prepare, clean and cut fish from whole (as well as having a go ourselves)- being able to ask very specific questions to guide my own cooking (I consider myself an amateur and keen cook, so this was very useful)- being shown the method how to prepare sushi (the guides showed each person our a group the correct technique) - enjoying the company of extremely helpful, pleasant and responsive guides (a great atmosphere to prepare food and eat together)This was definitely a highlight of our ten day Tokyo trip (and it's our third time to Japan in as many years).

An experience of a lifetime!. My daughter booked both the Auction Tour and Sushi Class, so we were committed to spending 3:30 AM to 1 PM (9 hours) with the dynamic duo of Tsubasa and Morita. Tsubasa, our guide, is an entrepreneur of many interests, with a broad knowledge of the Tsukiji market. He gave us much information in the wee small hours as we waited to go to the auction. His expertise was apparent and he managed the group well. Morita sprung into action during the shopping of the inner market. So many fish, so little time. The sushi workshop allowed time for two chefs (Morita +one) to demo their skills and then invite participants to try their hand at fish scaling and filleting. My kid did us proud! Lastly, we got to make our own little nigiri with a dab of freshly grated wasabi (Tsubasa's touch) and lay on slices of five different fishes. Both Tsubasa and Morita were friendly and personable with a great sense of humor. Made the whole experience so worthwhile. You are on the top of our list for recommendations to friends with Tokyo on their minds.

interesting.... It was an interesting workshop. We walked around the busy Tsukiji market to search for the fishes. Morita-san would explain how to choose the best fish. Once we got the fishes, they showed us how to prepare the fishes, by removing the bones and slicing the fishes. Definitely not easy! Some of us got to try the slicing of the fishes. After the fishes were prepared, we got down to preparing the sushi itself. We learned the techniques of kneading the rice into the correct shape using our hands and placing the fish on the rice. The chefs were very friendly and would patiently teach us. Good for those who are interested to learn making sushi from the natives.

We loved the Tuna Auction Tour!. I must say what while you can Auctions for free, the experience was vastly better having Tsubasa as our guide. He made sure we were in the right place at the right time, made sure we had a great viewing position, and most importantly, explained and translated the auction for us.. (so we actually knew the prices the fish were going for). Afterwards he took us through the internal market which was phenomenal! We saw such an amazing variety and quantity of fish, including seeing the giant Tuna being filleted with the large "Maguro bocho" knives (think Sword).We bought some wonderfully fresh scallops and sea urchin, which we ate for breakfast (prepared for us by a local restaurant alongside some other wonderful sashimi)An incredible experience.Notes: 1. Inside we saw whale meat openly for sale. I didn't expect it to be so open.2. I do warn you to wear shoes/pants than you don't mind get a bit wet/fishy if you venture into the internal market. (It is a busy place and the people there are busy working so you might brush against them)
Sushi workshop at Tokyo fish market. Great experience with professional sushi master in the hearth of Japan biggest fish market! Perfect organization and interesting tour of Tsukiji district.

Wonderful Sushi Making experience. it was great to have toured and made purchases of the raw materials for our workshop. This is once in a lifetime experience with the great hospitality and skillfulness from the chef and the tour guide. My son and I not only enjoyed the fruits of our harvest but also now have a common liking of making sushi to enhance our mother-son bondage.

An Incredible Experience!. It's been weeks since I took the cooking class in Tokyo, but I am still thinking about it. I’ve had countless meals and sushi since I returned to the states, but nothing remotely compares to what I had at this cooking class. We first started off the cooking class by making a trip to the market at around 8:30am. Tsubasa and Mr. Morita were both extremely welcoming and friendly and knowledgeable about the market and industry. As we walked around the market, the two of them explained how to pick good fish as well as the history and general mannerisms of the fish market. Mr. Morita has been a chef in the area for many years, so he knew everyone – literally shadowing a local for a few hours in both the inner and outer fish market. Tsubasa and Mr. Morita were especially good at taking into account what I wanted to eat, and we ended up picking scallops (still in the shell and oh so delightful), tuna (didn’t know tuna this good existed on Earth) and sea bass (cannot stop thinking about the sweet richness). The cooking class after we picked out the fish was extremely comprehensive, and I learned how to skin the fish, descale it, clean it, cut it, and make sushi with it. My teachers were extremely patient and the filled with laughter; eating, making sushi, more eating and lots of jokes in between, I felt not only to have learned so much, but also to have made new friends – a true cultural exchange. What an amazing and unforgettable experience. I love that I was able to share this tradition and art and integrate myself into the culture. Definitely a highlight to my trip – thank you for making this possible!

Excellent workshop. Very educational and fun. We started by visiting the inner market with Morita-san and Tsubasa-san (the sushi chef and translator/guide), learning about how to pick which fish to buy (each fish can be different), and about preserving them in the right way for making the tastiest sushi. Afterwards, we headed to a communal kitchen where we learned to fillet each fish, and finished by making our own sushi lunches!Both Morita-san (the sushi chef) and Tsubasa-san (the translator) were fantastic. Highly recommended!

One of my highlights of my trip to Japan. One of my highlights of my trip to Japan. Thank you guys. A great morning spent at the market and Kitchen. Nothing was to much of a problem. Would highly recommend this to anyone.
Great day at the Market and Kitchen!. Great experience! Market for shopping and then prepare and eat your own sushi! Dont miss it if you like seafood and your passion is cuisine!

Great foodie experience!. This was a great experience from the start of the tour to the last delicious piece of sushi! It was a great way to learn about the market, which would have been very intimidating without our guide. My husband was proud to show off his knife skills to the sushi master, Mr. Morita. Tsubasa was a very enthusiastic guide and we had a great time talking with him. As food lovers, this tour and workshop absolutely met our very high expectations!!

Sushi workshop. Absolutely loved the experience. The fish market tour and sushi making process was very insightful and rewarding. Nothing was lost in translation and so many wonderful flavors were experienced. A great way to spend the morning while on a short or long trip to Tokyo.

"Amazing Sushi Experience". My girlfriend and I are avid sushi fans. We found this to be a great experience to see the famous Tsukiji fish market firsthand and learn the ins and outs of Sushi making from an experienced Sushi chef. Staff Hiro and Tsubasa were very friendly and enthusiastic about there craft. I honestly never knew how intensive the sushi making process is and found this course to be very informative and culturally rich.This is a great experience for those who love sushi and want to gain a better appreciation of Japanese culture. Overall a great experience and I would recommend to anyone goin gto Tokyo.

Great sushi workshop . Our group of three spent an hour in the fish market learning how to select fresh fish and shellfish. We then went to their studio where about 7 different fish and shellfish were prepared we had the opportunity to fillet the fish or open and prep the shellfish. We them learned how to hand roll the sushi and then eat it. We made fresh wasabi too, which was so much cleaner and milder than store bought. It was a 4.5 hour day and well worth it

Great experience!!!. Actually Tsubasa was my guide for the tuna auction at the Tsukiji market! He came to meet me at my place as I wouldn't have a clue on how to get there.He is very knowledgeable, and we could get to the place at the right time to be one of the 120 people allowed to see the auction. He knows a lot about the fishes and food, and made the wait goes very pleasent.After the auction we walked around the area, and bought some fresh seafood for our breakfast we had at a nice place, where I met the chef Hirobumi Morita!During the tour Tsubasa mentioned about the workshop and if it is as good as his guidance through the market, it will be great!!
