We finished our meals with mochi and matcha tea. I recommend this cooking class without any hesitation.

Great cooking class. I had taken one of Arigato's food tours a few months earlier and was so impressed that despite being the world's worst cook I wanted to check out one of Arigatou's cooking classes. Like the food tour, the cooking class was led by a highly knowledgeable Japanese instructor fluent in English. We made a delicious meal including しょうが焼き, I was amazed by how easy it was and how good the results were. The cooking experience will appeal both to those new to Japanese food and those with a lot of knowledge.

Awesome Tokyo Food & Drink Walking Tour. We loved this tour... exceeded our expectations! This was our first visit to Japan, and food and drink (90% plus of menus are in Japanese kanji) was a bit of a challenge, not knowing what you're ordering. So being guided was something we were looking forward to. Our guide, Ayumi, was wonderful. She did everything possible to be a great host, inform, entertain, and keep our small group moving. She provided a great balance of factual information and storytelling about Japan and Tokyo, more than enough to fill the three hours.We most enjoyed going in to small, out-of-the-way spots that tourists wouldn't visit on their own. Yakitori and plum wine at the first spot. Yum! A walk-through of a high-end Ginza department store food hall (kind of like Harrod's). Multiple dishes at the next spot... Japanese cucumber and miso dip, dumpling stew, fried chicken and delicious dip, yakisoba, a sardine pizza (we're not crazy about fish), egg omelette and a dessert treat. Delicious, fun and much more food than expected! Personal recommendation: try plum wine with club soda (a sort of plum wine "spritzer), especially if it's a warm day. Awesome!After a bit more walking, Ayumi had us stop at a sidewalk shop and bought us custard-filled fish-shaped waffles called Taiyaki, after showing us a beautiful, little out-of-the way Shinto shrine down a Tokyo alley.The experience is well worth the price and we would "highly recommend." It's an outstanding mixture of food, culture, sights, information and pleasant little surprises. You won't regret this tour.

Amazing experience. We joined the washoku class and really had an amazing time with our teacher Shirley..she was awesome! We learned how to make a traditional dashi from scratch! We made pork with ginger, tamagoyaki and 2 traditional side dishes! It was the highlight of our trip. Thanks to Arigato Japan for this amazing experience!

Excellent food tour. This is a must when in Tokyo. We loved every minute of it and should have done it the first night we arrived. Anne is the best tour guide especially if one is English speaking. Anne took us to a variety of places in three different districts and also to an exclusive department store for food tastings. The food floor was an extravaganza - with the presentation exceptional. We ate so much food and had to leave some Please do this tour as I can't rate it highly enough. Thank you Anne for providing such a great experience.

An unforgettable experience!. My mother and I came to Japan to bond and when I found out we'd be learning how to cook from a Japanese chef i was really up for it. The experience was great and the chef is really patient. My chefs name was ayumi and she would explain what and why the cooking process does. I'm really happy that now I can come back home and say that I went to Japan and learned how to cook katsu from a real Japanese chef. Anne was also very accommodating, making my mother and I feel comfortable and at home. I had to postpone our sushi making class; however, it will be the first thing I do when I come back to Japan!! Thank you again Anne and Ayumi for the unforgettable experience!!!

A Must When in Japan. We joined Arigato Japan's Bento Making class and it was so fun , engaging and really wonderful! Our teacher, Shirley, was very professional and had proper training to teach this class. She was extremely patient and taught us everything we need to know about japanese cooking. We started the class by making dashi , I had no idea that doing it the traditional way definitely made the food taste better! It was unbelievably good and nutritious! After this we made 3 other side dishes, the tamagoyaki or Japanese egg omelette was so fun for me and my husband we ended up making them when we came back to the US! Shirley taught us how to make a super easy and really tasty pumpkin with sesame seed side dish, it was so yummy! Finally we made some grilled teriyaki fish, this was definitely the highlight of the class! I've never made fish this good, thank you to Arigato for teaching me the simplest techniques I definitely didn't know about! What an enjoyable and fun class!I have attended two other cooking classes in our previous trips in Japan but this obento class with Arigato Japan was definitely the best!!! Highly recommended, they even gave us recipes that we have already used with some of our meals! A must try cooking class in Tokyo!!

Much more then a food tour!. We took the Allstar TokyoFood Tour with Anne as our guide.She is charming and knowledgable and provided us with a fun and educational evening. In addition to lots of good food that that the average tourist might not try she provided a lot of insight into Japanese culture and an introduction into parts of Tokyo that we would have never seen on our own.

Great Classes!. Took the sushi class about a month ago and it was fantastic!! I chose this class due to it being close to my boyfriend's new apartment without knowing much about it. He and I loved it (despite finding out that we have very little actual sushi-making talent). We have even sought out the materials to attempt making at home. Highly recommend to all. Also, side note: Anne and staff are so much fun and a wealth of knowledge when it comes to Tokyo's food and drink scene-- She has been a great resource to me.

Food secrets of Tokyo. This was the highlight of a week in Tokyo. We live in Japan and had family in visiting. Anne made this a very special 3+ hours. Her knowledge of the Japanese culture and her passion for sharing experiences was obvious and contagious. We we to several small izakayas (sp) that we never would have even seen, let alone found. The variety of foods that we tasted was amazing for the short time. We had yakitori, noodles, chicken that was incredible, vegetables, sake, highballs, and beer. We also were able to taste some outstanding Japanese sweets. While walking through the neighborhoods, Anne was able to share some wonderful knowledge and insights. As wonderful and the locations and food was, Anne was the best part. She was fun, passionate, and knowledgeable and really went out of her way to make sure that everyone had a great time. I have been on several food tours and this was the best.

Mr. A unique look at Tokyo's food culture with informative and friendly guide through Tokyo's streets, the conversations and information were almost as good as the food ( which was perfection! ) A highlight of the trip.

A Fantastic Tokyo Food Experience. This was the greatest tour!! We walked around for three hours with stops at wonderful restaurants, assorted shops and even a depachika, which is what the Japanese call the food store in the basement level of a department store. It was amazing!We sampled all kinds of incredible foods. Our first stop was at a small yakitori restaurant where we ate five types of yakitori, drank plum wine and I had my first ever highball (it was really good)! Anne explained that the highball, which is made with whiskey and club soda, had become a very popular drink in Japan.Anne is a fantastic guide. She speaks English like a US native and it was like walking around Tokyo with an old friend. In addition to the food and drink, she took us to the smallest police station in Tokyo, showed us where to buy a forty dollar melon and explained why it costs so much and much more.Our final stop was at a restaurant which specializes in food from the Kyushu region of Japan. We started the meal with raw cucumber and cabbage that we dipped in a fantastic miso dip. Then dumpling stew, Japanese fried chicken, yakisoba, and our favorite, the tender grilled chicken bits that we dipped into a spicy yuzu seasoning before eating it. Heavenly!I should add that she took a lot of photos and even some videos, which she sent to us afterwards. If you're ever in Tokyo, take this tour!!!

Highly recommend you take this tour!. I went on the All-Star Tokyo Food Tour, and thanks to a group of six who cancelled last minute, I got a private tour with Anne. I can't recommend her tour enough. She's warm and friendly and her English is 100% fluent. When she found out I was spending only one day in Tokyo and had seen next to nothing, she changed up our route on the fly and made sure that I got to see more Tokyo landmarks. It's clear she loves meeting people and showing off the city. She even put in a huge effort to try and find me a manicure appointment the next morning - highly beyond the call of duty. I spent a lot of time choosing a food tour, and I'm glad I chose this one.

We attended a class with Arigato Japan and it was the highlight of our trip. We attended a class with Arigato Japan and it was the highlight of our trip, what an amazing experience! I usually attend cooking classes when I travel and this by far was the friendliest, most hands on and very engaging class ever! Shirley was a very fun teacher that guided us from making our first sushi. Imagine making not one , but three amazing sushis in two hours! The flower sushi was extremely fun, the ingredients used in class were absolutely yummy and very fresh! We tried lots of local ingredients and sashimi and was very full by the end of the class. Lunch was served with three side dishes, soup and an amazing japanese dessert with green tea! I will definitely recommend this class to anyone in tokyo! Thanks tripadvsor!!! Really helped us have an unforgettable experience in Japan!!!

A great way to experience real Japanese cooking first-hand!. We discovered Arigato Japan Food Tours and Cooking Classes through Reddit, and it seemed like a fun thing to do on our first visit to Japan. It turned out to be a great choice! We opted for the obento course, where we made a proper Japanese lunch consisting of teriyaki chicken, tamagoyaki (egg rolls), miso soup, steamed spinach and seasoned rice, all fashionably presented in an obento box (or at least we tried!)Our teacher was highly prepared, very patient, and not only did she teach us about Japanese lunches, but talked about her own experiences, upbringing and everyday life, and we really felt we learned a lot about food and lunch culture in Japan. On top of that, we got a really tasty lunch, in addition to the crash course in Japanese cuisine. The course took place in an apartment building, we had a little trouble finding it because we expected something more commercial, but it was at the address as stated, a short walk from the subway - you just had to go through a hallway by some mail boxes and up an elevator, it was clearly marked from there. And to be honest, cooking in what felt more like a home had a lot of charm.The course itself was a lot of fun, we enjoyed trying to cook with chopsticks, but were luckily offered a trusty spatula. We have a lot of learning to do, that's for sure. We learned about different seasonings and common everyday Japanese ingredients, and how a regular breakfast and lunch looks like - much different from the bread based food we usually have in Norway. We were the only course participants that day, and had the teacher to ourselves, which was really nice, and allowed us to talk quite a bit.I would recommend this to anyone who wants a genuine Japanese experience, couples, families, young or old. They also offer Food Tours, which we are keen on trying the next time we're travelling to Japan, as well as the other cooking courses. All in all, it was a charming and fun experience, with a crew that really love what they are doing!

All stars walking food tour. Great way to get to know your way around Tokyo, we got to see 3 great area including Ginza and Shimbashi. I loved that we got to eat Japanese food specialities from all over Japan . There was plenty of tasty dishes and we all went home satisfied and very happy to have done the tour.

Experience Tokyo like a local, an absolute MUST. I arrived in Tokyo after having read two guide books and several articles online. After touring the city using the guide books I thought I had experienced all that Tokyo had to offer. Boy was I wrong! The guide books barely scratched the surface. Nothing compares to experiencing a city with a local guide, they tell you things you won’t find in books and take you off the beaten path. Anne was an absolutely perfect guide. Warm and pleasant from the second I met her. She was extremely knowledgeable about Tokyo and Japan and took me on a tour around the city to places and areas only the locals know about. She explained in great detail the history of each area as well as the food I enjoyed. Possibly the most enjoyable part of the tour was the cultural emersion. Anne explained the many cultural nuances of Japan/Tokyo and I finished the tour with a much greater understanding and appreciation of the country and its people. I had such a good time I booked two more tours that week. Anne also helped me set up my trip to the rest of Japan, which was invaluable. Not only would I strongly recommend the Arigato Japan experience I actually believe it is a must if you want to truly experience Tokyo from a local perspective.

A "taste" of local culture. We had the sushi making class and I can definitely say that it was a worthwhile experience! We had so much fun cooking and we had the chance to soak up some of the food history of Japan. It’s definitely a must-try especially for tourists who wish to experience a bit of the local culture, more than just the typical sight-seeing. The class was well organized and everyone, especially Ms. Anne, were incredibly knowledgeable and friendly! This would be a good family activity as well since instructions are clear and simple, even kids would surely enjoy. As a plus of course you get to have a full meal - we left there feeling stuffed! I hope to go back again someday with the family and try the walking food tour as well. A big thanks to Arigato Japan and Ms. Anne for the lovely experience!

It's a unique, fun and memorable Tokyo experience!. We were in Tokyo for a business trip and was fortunate enough to have met Ms. Anne and be invited to her Sushi-making class! I really love Japanese food so I was very excited to attend it! While interactively learning how to make sushi, we also found out a lot about its interesting history. And most importantly, I'm so glad I actually made and eat my own delicious sushi! :D Try out this class for a taste of authentic Japanese food culture. It's such a unique travel experience! Thank you, Ms. Anne and Arigato Japan Food Tours and Cooking Classes!

We love Arigato Japan!. My husband and I had a very wonderful experience making maki and sushi at Arigato Japan! We used the basic ingredients necessary in Japanese cooking. The class was very well organized, time was used wisely, and we even had the chance to make our own salad dressing from miso for our side dish. We were able to make dashi - the traditional way! Sushi rice making was also one of the highlights of this class! We are extremely excited to make the temari sushi with our family very soon! They even handed out some recipes for all of the dishes we made. It was a great cultural experience. Ms. Shirley, our instructor was very hands on and knowledgable. We highly recommend this class, you will definitely enjoy it the way we!!!

Arigato Japan Food Tours. I am from New Zealand, but live in Tokyo and recently had a friend visit me from NZ. We joined the food tour around Ginza and had a wonderful time walking the back streets and eating delicious food in little Japanese restaurants - not to mention the very good Sake ! After eating at several restaurants, we then moved on to the bright lights of the Ginza shopping area where we were amazed at the beautiful presentation of food.We made new friends on the night and had a very lovely, bright and spunky tour guide - Anne. It was a very relaxing evening and a great way to enjoy and embrace the amazing food and culture of Japan and I highly recommend the experience.

Amazing, Educational & Fun. My husband & I had a wonderful time learning how to make sashimi & sushi. The history that was given about Sushi along with the country was very appropriately paired with the cooking. We definitely recommend this for anyone looking to expand their horizons and have an extra special time in Tokyo. Anne is very sweet and knowledgeable and was instrumental in our fun there. She really knows her stuff. We plan to come back and do a food tour next time!

Sushi and Maki Class. The sushi and maki class from Arigato Japan Food Tours and Cooking Classes was wonderful! We were looking for a cooking experience while in Japan and this did not disappoint. It was a great perk having a private class where we could chat with the chef and owner and ask specific questions as we went about the food, the culture, the area, and just getting to know them. The class was 2 hours long and we were involved in every step as we created our lunch for the day! From making great sushi rice to the art of rolling sushi- this is wonderfully hands-on. You end up having soup, sushi, maki, a few appetizer size sides, and dessert! We were stuffed! A great class!

The cooking class was well worth it. I initially booked to attend the walking tour organized by Arigato Japan but due to a mix-up on my part, I couldn't make it to the meeting time. Anne was kind enough to reach out and invite me to attend the bento box cooking class happening the next day to make up for it.It ended up being a very rewarding and informative experience! The instructors were friendly and gave us a good backstory on Japanese cuisine and cooking techniques. They were able to answer questions with no problems. Most importantly, the food itself was delicious and very filling. I typically find miso soup somewhat bland, but the one we made during the class was rich with flavour. Anne also took photos throughout and posted them on Facebook so that we could look back on the experience and share them with our friends. I was grateful for that as it allowed me to focus fully on the lesson without needing to take my own photos. We were also given a copy of the recipe. I can't wait to try replicating the dishes at home!Highly recommended for first-time visitors of Japan.

Food tour and cooking class. Me and my family did the Arigato Japan food walking tour on our first day in Tokyo and it was by far the best way to start the trip. Anne was an amazing guide, her enthusiasm and love for her job showed throughout the tour while she explained the history of the city, Japanese culture, and all the hidden gems she took us to and marvelous food they had to offer. Later Anne told us of a sushi class that they offered and me and my boyfriend quickly signed up. It was an awesome experience that we can take home and continue to practice. It was only four of us so we were able to get one on one help from the teacher. The teachers were so nice and patience and answered all of our questions. I would definitely do these tours again next time I go to Japan and would highly recommend to anyone looking to get a quality tour in Tokyo.

Arigato to Arigato Japan!. What a fabulous class at Arigato Japan! My teenage daughter and I were in Tokyo for vacation. We wanted a homestyle culture experience. Signed up for the Maki and Sushi making class. Anne and Tomoko were our host and instructor. Lesson covered for:Flower SushiTemari SushiDashiOsuimono SoupAnne provided a background coverage of sushi and how it came about in Japan. Tomoko demonstrated how to make dashi and osuimono soup. She showed us the proportions used and the visuals to look out for in making the broth. As simple as it was, there was a full science behind watching the temperature and timing to execute this flavorful broth. She also gave us pointers for other uses of this broth. Our hands-on participation came in the sushi prep work. We learned to flavor, cool and mix the sushi rice. The rolling and forming was quite a skill to learn. Tomoko was very encouraging as this was our first time making sushi. We had a palette of ingredients to work with. Each of our sushi was created to reflect our personal style. Next was the best part, we ate our creations! Complimented by the soup, side dishes, green tea and followed by dessert. Learning and eating is the best combination. Anne provided information on the ingredients used and where I can buy these groceries locally. We even got recommendations for various local attractions to the rest of our vacation.

Delicious, Inviting, and Informative!. Book this tour. It really was an incredible experience. Anne and Yoske were so great! The food was awesome, and it was exactly the kind of "where we wouldn't have gone on our own" experience that we were searching for. There really is nothing like visiting a country and getting a first hand account from locals about what it is like to live there. This tour is full of great history, and stories, and you get to eat the whole time! I couldn't recommend it more.

A very fun activity.. I attended a cooking class run by Sherry and Ayumi, it was a very fun class I was joined by 2 other solo travelers and Anne, who greeted us at the beginning of the class and documented the lesson with photos. The location was very easy to find, I'm always afraid of getting lost looking for places like this, but as long as you can navigate the metro and various train lines you can get here.The space wasn't large but the right size for an intimate feeling class. I'll admit that there was from time to time a little confusion but the instructors admitted they were new and their attitudes and attention more than made up for a few moments here and there when things weren't perfectly smooth.The method of instruction was very good, the ingredients and techniques were all explained and demonstrated with opportunities to try them out. They made sure each of us understood what was happening and and going on. After cooking we set up the bento boxes and tucked in to some tasty food followed by tea and sweets, we were supplied with recipes but... I only received one page of mine. :( I recommended Arigato Japan to people looking to see insight into the kinds of foods, and flavors that Japan has to offer. Our class was filled with laughter, good food, and will be a highlighted memory of this trip to Japan.

Great start to our trip to Japan!. We took the food tour on the evening of our first full day in Tokyo. Not only did we learn about the different types of restaurants and see some of the city, but we also learned some basic table manners and customs. Both restaurants were very good and the guides gave very detailed descriptions of the food and drinks that we tried. A great start to our visit to Japan.

Arigato Japan Walking Food Tour - Highlight of our Trip. I booked the walking food tour for me and my girlfriend through Arigato Japan. The tour was the highlight of our trip - Anne was knowledgeable and friendly, and brought us to try a bunch of restaurants that we would not have otherwise discovered. The food and desserts were amazing. Additionally, she took pictures and made a video for us to help us remember our trip. We highly recommend their walking food tour.

Anne is my hero. This tour is a must! I was traveling with four of my friends in March. We had to change our plans last-minute and head to Tokyo a day early. On the train to Tokyo, I messaged Anne at Arigato Food Tours to see if they had any tours left that evening. We were in luck! Anne was super responsive and unbelievably patient. We had trouble storing our luggage upon arrival and she offered to help us out with that (way above and beyond), we got lost getting to our accommodation and were 45 minutes late to the tour, but she was still smiling when we finally arrived and, feeling our stress levels, spent the next couple of hours familiarizing us with the overwhelming city and making us feel comfortable. The food on the tour was phenomenal- every stop offered something exciting and delicious. Not only were we able to try out a variety of traditional Japanse food, but she introduced us to a couple of the different 'boroughs' of Tokyo...suggesting great places to visit over the next couple of days. Anne has a clear love for the city and a passion for the food it has to offer. She also has a clear passion for making people have fun and feel comfortable. She honestly was our Tokyo hero, making us feel much more confident about tackling the city on our own!

Informative and eye opening. This was a great little food tour around Ginza with a very knowledgeable tour guide. The highlight was seeing the local Gado Shita, which are little hidden restaurants built up under the brick arches beneath the train track.I feel my experience was slightly marred by the fact that I was the only person on the tour. Although it was great to have a personal guide, it wasn't quite what I was expecting being a solo traveler. However, i was able to get a wealth of information from the guide which I was wonderful.Wear comfortable working shoes, come with questions and take a chance on something you've not eaten before (like raw chicken)!

Great food tour experience!. As I was searching through the web on what to do on weekends, randomly, I came across to this "Walking Food Tour" thing and it rang a bell to my ear as it was the first time that I have heard about food tours in Tokyo. This is my first time to experience a food tour and it did not disappoint me. The owner herself was very friendly and passionate about food in Japan. She has a tour guide that was very knowledgeable and approachable. It was fun as I got to taste Japanese street foods that I have never tasted before. And also got the chance to walk around the city. I would highly recommend this tour for those who want to experience something new and exciting.

Walking Food Tour. This food tour was amazing!!!It was such a delight meeting Elizabeth Anne within hours of arriving in Tokyo, her English is perfect . The food was great, she took us to local food spots which we would have never experienced without doing the tour. Anne Incorporated the foods tour with a bit of history which was very informative. Thanks so much you helped to make our vacation perfect.

Touring Ginza with Kanemoto. My wife and I booked a food tour with Arigato as we had read good reviews, and we wanted to familiarize ourselves with local food spots. Sometimes we prefer to do these things with other tourists, but it was just us and our guide, Kanemoto. And of course it was awesome. Kanemoto was awesomely knowledgeable, and took us all around Ginza pointing out historical sights, and plenty of modern areas that we would have never found. He took us in a department store which sounds silly, but actually was great, and even bought us a fancy dessert for after dinner. We went to an izikaya where we drank some sake, beer, and ate grilled skewers of chicken. We walked thru the tight spots under the train observing locals getting off work and unwinding. We ate chicken sashimi hesitantly, but once in our mouths there was no regret: It was damn good. Kanemato would tell us about the food, and also about Kabuki. All in all, we had a great time with Kanemoto, and we are glad we took the tour.

Amazing wagashi cooking class. The wagashi class ("wagashi" meaning "Japanese sweet") was absolutely fantastic!In two hours, we made two kinds of pastries, had a little bit of history about desserts in Japan and ended by a lovely tea ceremony. Naoko, our chef, was full of a beautiful energy and happy to share her knowledge.It has honestly been one of the best moments of my last trip to Tokyo.I highly recommend any traveller to try one (or more) of their classes :)

Sushi Cooking class . Had a great time at Arigatojapan. We made delicious soup and learned how to make sushi. Teachers are very friendly and nice. It's in a small and apartment. They speak a very good English. Will come back to an other class.

Cooking class with great food. This was a really nice experience in Tokyo. We live here and brought friends from Sweden visiting us. We were 3 adults and 4 children from 8-14 years old. We all had a really nice time making sushi looking like flowers and our own designed different creations. The children also really liked that they could be creative and loved the result of what they made. I can highly recommend this cooking class suitable for both families and adults.

Wonderful Walking Food Tour, We Were Very Full!. We thoroughly enjoyed this walking food tour of Tokyo with Elizabeth Anne! After finally making our way to the meeting spot, she walked right up to us to confirm who we were (I'm sure we looked a little lost), and then off we went! We stopped at a few scheduled bars/pubs for food and drink and were pretty much full after the first stop. But the food did not stop, nor did the conversation! We also enjoyed hearing about the city from a local, everything from food and dining, to current events and what it's like to live in the city! We also passed by a few places that weren't on the tour (at our request) to hear about some history. We sat and enjoyed a few more locations before wrapping up - and there was no hurry to end! I felt like we could have been out all night. Had we not been jet-lagged, that probably would have been the case. This tour was the perfect first full night in Tokyo for us and gave us a better idea of the different parts of town too. I'd recommend Elizabeth Anne to anyone, and will reach out to her again on our next visit.

Arigato Japan Cooking Class. Learning to make Dashi and Maki was so much with Arigato Japan. Booking process was very efficient and friendly, nothing was too hard. I can now make these recipes with confidence and hope to do come back again to do a tour with Arigato Japan. Thank you

Wonderful. A fantastic outing into a series of local taverns, upscale shops, intimate back streets and broad avenues.Delightful tour companions - Sebastien and Stefan. Anna was a joy as our tourguide - personable, full of factual and fun information, giving us some great insights into Japanese culture, business and family life.Then, there was the food! - superb, beautifully presented, varied, and served to us by friendly thoughtful waitstaff in all the venues we visited. A local patron at one of the izakayas came over and visited with us.One of the best food tours we have ever experienced. Don't think about it - just call them and set it up! (I have no relationship with the tour other than as a supremely satified customer)

Delicious and informative!. I've lived in Japan for three years. I took my visiting parents on Anne's tour, and we had a blast!She'd really done her homework; the places she took us were great finds. Throughout the walk, she was a constant source of useful info, history, and background.From the significance of Yurakucho during the 1923 earthquake to the ubiquitous depachika "culinary amusement parks" found underneath every department store in Tokyo, Anne's tour has it all.You won't be disappointed!

Vacation. We were able to enjoy tokyo like a local, food was just amazing, very high quality, Makiko san the guide was exceptionally great! The tour was the highlight of our trip and super enjoyable!!

Excellent food tour in Tokyo. We had 4 days in Tokyo and wanted to see the best of it, particularly the culinary side. As foodies, we always seek out the best cooking schools and food tours on offer and this is what set Arigato apart for us when researching.From the outset, Anne was a pleasure to deal with. She was quick to respond to us. She's an extremely endearing and warm person who you will quickly fall in love with.She showed us round the izakayas of Yurakucho, Ginza and Shinbashi, focusing on the ones serving the best quality. We saw this in izakaya we'd previous visited by ourselves and had been a bit disappointed by the quality of the meat (language barrier didn't help of course). Anne knows the best ones who use fresh ingredients - everything we tried was delicious, particularly the yaki tori (chicken skewer BBQ) and miso prizes in the final izakaya.Oh - look out for the raw chicken sashimi. This divided us as you can expect - but you have to try it!Excellent tour, good value for money and a great way to get a taster of Tokyo for first timers - or even for those (like us) returning to the city for their 2nd visit.

Great food tour . This is such a nice and different way to see Tokyo. The food is nice and you learn a lot about the Japanese culture and the history of Isakayas in Tokyo. Anne is a great host, very friendly with perfect English. We had an amazing time and would definitely recommend her tours.

Update on Ichigo Daifuku (Strawberry Mochi) class -Apr 22nd. I am updating the review that my friend and I wrote on 22nd Apr. The owner, Anne responded very quickly and was very apologetic. She refunded us the full amount we paid for the class, along with a gift. We appreciated her action and she took this as a learning lesson. In the future, we may take a class from her again.

Maki and Sushi class -an unforgettable time in Tokyo!. We had an amazing time with my family making sushi, it was such a fun and really engaging class. The staff were all friendly, Kishi sensei was very accommodating and hands on. We will never forget this really great class, the food was very fresh and yummy! We will try their walking food tour next time :)

Amazing and fun experience. This is my first time joining a cooking class and it sure was a wonderful experience, the teachers were nice and the overall atmosphere of the place was very friendly makes you wanna really get into it and learn more. Now I'm not very good with cooking or well handling food very good I'd say so myself, but I really do feel like I improved. I definitely recommend this cooking class for anyone who's interested.

The client well satisfied. They will surely remember me, Im Danny i have diabetes, I attended their Wagashi class the one with the tea ceremony and strawberries, they made me some special ingredients because they know how to balance the glucose level I should take, and the owner even try to check thru the net the sugar level of each ingredients:) thank you Arigato Japan! Recommended experience to everyone

Great time learning!. Kudos to Arigato Japan for coming up with amazing classes! Love that their Japanese teachers can really speak English fluently. I didn't have any problem on understanding the lesson. The kitchen was very nice, modern, neat place too. I really had a great time learning Japanese cuisine!

Fun, Friendly, and EASY!. I did the sushi course, and the wagashi course! I'm so so so bad at Japanese Cooking, even though I've lived in Japan for more than ten years myself, but these classes were fun and easy, and gave me the confidence I need to go home and re-create these dishes in my own home in Southern Japan.The teachers were very friendly, especially Naoko-sensei, from our Japanese Sweets Class, she has so much energy, and a great sense of humor! I loved her lesson so much.I think I'll try the Walking Tours next time! :)P.S, I am a video blogger and I will be posting video reviews of both lessons online, but I'd also like to formally apologize to anyone who felt uncomfortable or was inconvenienced by our shooting. I know how annoying it is to deal with people like us. :)

Ichigo Daifuku (Strawberry Mochi) class - Apr 22nd. When my friend and I stepped into the class, I felt that it was a little unorganized. There was a teacher, the owner, and 2 helpers in a small apartment. They were busy cleaning and it looked unprepared. We waited until 3 more students showed up. And the nightmare begins when she introduced us to 2 video bloggers that walked in! As you can imagine, how the class went. It was very distracting. I know this is a great publicity but it is not fair to those who paid for the class and really wanted to learn. The bloggers were constantly taking videos of themselves and did not bother asking permission from us when they were taking pictures. It was very unprofessional of the owner. She couldn't remember how much she advertised the class for and we paid 4900 ¥ each. When we returned home, I found out that it was posted on the Facebook page for 9500 ¥ for two. The teacher was good but she put more attention in bringing in props for the tea ceremony presentation. There was confusion on how many daifuku we get to make and we only ended making one each. Once the class ended we fled. On the way out, I expressed my disappointment and she apologized but it was a little too late for that. She knew that 2 video bloggers were attending the class. When we signed up for the class she could have mentioned it to us. I would pay a little more for a class at Buddha Bellies Cooking School. I guess you pay for what you get! I will email a copy of this review to the owner, Anne and give her a chance to explain. Will update later if she does.

Amazing Creativity/Full with Passion. I visited my sister in Tokyo for one week. On our bonding moments we decided to join this cooking class. Wow! What a wonderful experience. What an amazing creativity, so many ideas to choose from and you really learn a lot... and it's created with passion & most importantly the taste is sooo good!Looking forward to join this class again together with my sister. Hopefully next year! Domo Arigato.

Recommended . I've had a great time! The instructors are very friendly and impressionable they take time answering questions. I will definitely be going back to get to know more recipe. Thumbs up on how they instruct and for a well done cooking class.

An Unforgettable and Inexpensive Pleasure. I had an amazing time with the Cooking class, the food was just great and the class exceeded my expectation! We have learned how to cook Japanese food in the Japanese way. A lot better than Youtube for sure! This is definitely a great way of spending a day in Tokyo! Our host, Anne was extremely knowledgeable and very friendly! We're looking forward of attending the maki class on our next visit. Highly recommended!

Great experience even for "know-it-all" expats and local Japanese. I went with a small group of Japanese and expat friends, many of us having lived in Japan for many years and most of us fluent in Japanese, wondering how much we could really learn from a food tour in ginza. A lot, it turns out ! Besides uncovering some real hidden gem restaurants, the guide's narration about the history of the neighborhood and little-known facts about Japanese cuisine were well-researched and entertaining. The quality of food and drink was top notch. Would definitely recommend to both visitors and Japan residents.

Enlightening Enteraining and Easy. A total Must do!. What a wonderful way to spend my morning in Tokyo. Not only did we learn to create delightfully delicate delicious sushi we learnt all about the history of this "fast" food in Japan. It truly made me appreciate how everything in Japan especially food is painstakingly precise and complicated. I loved being crazy and creative with the sushi. One of the ladies taking the class with us made giant (onigiri) size Sushi and another participant made tiny pieces of perfection. Also you chat and connect with some great fun people. Elizabeth Anne who's brain child this venture is warm and welcoming and has put together an excellent team of English speaking local Japanese chefs who explain all the complicated detailed processes and recipes so simply. Since the class I have become addicted to a Jalapeños wasabi paste I was introduced to during the class. Yum!! Enlightening entertaining and easy. A Must must do.

Local food in tokyo. I would definitely come back in tokyo.... food was great... food was just amazing, very high quality, Makiko san the guide was exceptionally great! This was really the highlight of our trip. I woukd definitely recommend!

So much fun - a must-do in Japan!. I attended the cooking class and the walking tour; and I LOVED both! The cooking class was an insightful way to learn (and then eat!) sushi making and the walking tour showed me parts of Japan I would have probably missed! Will definitely be back to visit.

Awesome tour, awesome guide!. We only had a weekend in Tokyo and I'm so glad we chose to spend the first part of it with our awesome guide, Makiko san. Having a guide through the fish market truly enriched the experience and ensured some really good tasting experiences that we would not have had on our own.

A great evening! Enjoyed every moment!. Anne gave us a great evening! It started with warm welcome, beautiful tour, and an unforgettable evening on the side ways of Tokyo. We tasted many new dishes we never knew before and we know something about food and cooking. I will recommend my friends to discover Tokyo with Anne/Arigato.

Best idea while in Tokyo. Learning to make sushi with Anne and her team was one of the best decisions I made while in Tokyo. Her kitchen and facilities are white glove and the experience can't be beat!

My Giant Sushis. My schedule is so hectic that I seldom have time for leisure or exploits other than those work related.When Anne invited me to the Arigato Japan Cooking Class, I had to cancel a meeting to join the class. My son studies culinary arts so I wanted to surprise him with something that is related to his passion.I did not expect to enjoy the class so much but with the patient teachers/chefs and the friendly participants, it was actually a blast. My favorite part is the do it yourself sushi. I had the biggest and weirdest combination sushis but I love them. I also like the small size class. Everyone gets special attention. Thank you Elizabeth Anne for inviting me and thank you Arigato Japan Food Tours and Cooking Classes for enabling me to make sushi which I never imagine I cound. I will definitely try it again when I go back to my own country.Who knows? Maybe my budding chef will get an idea from me.

For food lovers!. When you visit Japan food is one major thing you must experience. I enjoyed the cooking classes from Arigato Japan, learning traditional Japanese cooking to indulging my passion for food made my visit unforgettable. The food tour was fun and insightful, we did the Ginza and Shibuya food tours! A must to do in Tokyo.

A Must Try. I’ve been to other cooking classes in the past and this is definitely the best one in terms of food preparation, friendly staff and easy to follow techniques. It was a very pleasant experience, this was definitely the highlight of my trip! Great location too!

A Great Tokyo Experience. I had the impression that Japanese food was hard to make- Kishi Sensei really helped me understand the basics of Japanese cooking. It was great how they clearly explained some techniques in how to cook the perfect sushi rice! I am very satisfied with their lesson, definitely worth going to if you are in Tokyo!

Great food, great people, a must see for anyone traveling to Japan!. Amazing instructors, food, and people. This is a must have on your travel list to Tokyo. You might think that this is for the older crowd, but don't be fooled, even as a solo traveller in my early twenties, I had such an amazing time and would easily recommend this to anyone. A truly unique experience for anyone that wants to not only experience Japanese culture, but bring it home and remember it for the rest of their lives.

Sushi en Maki Savvy 🍣🍱🍶. The concept of Arigato Japan is brilliant! For a family so young en still exploring like us, this is one of the best ways to engage in more so if you're touring in Japan. Sushi class is a fun-filled learning experience with accommodating teachers. In fact, my children also enjoyed it most especially the tasting / eating part of it . Location is accessible by trains en buses and can walk-through the areas of the famous Tokyo Tower and Roppongi. Now, we are loving sushi and maki even more!!! And the thoughts of going back to (Arigato) Japan is greater this time.

One of a kind EXPERIENCE 👍🏼. A MUST do if you are traveling to Tokyo, the classes are easy , fun and engaging, it's the best cooking school we've ever been to! Clean and well maintained place!!! We will definitely visit again soon! ☺️

Great Sushi Class!. I attended the class with a friend and we had a great time making flower and temari sushi! The English-speaking instructors walked us through the entire process from cooking the rice and prepping the ingredients to creating the final product, which in our case was lunch! The class was fun and really informative. The temari sushi is definitely going into my rotation of family dinners!

Japanese Cuisine Fanatic. We had an amazing time taking this class.It had the perfect ambiance for Japanese cooking. Naoko sensei, was extremely knowledgeable. She was very warm and accommodating! The class was very fun and informative. The key ingredients of Japanese cooking were all explained to us and this was extremely important to a chef like me. This is a highly recommended class if you are in Tokyo, I was able to recreate the sushi and Maki in my own catering events here in Orange County, CA. Thanks to these guys from Arigato Japan!

Mother-Daughter cooking lesson. I took the maki & sushi class with my adult daughter, her friend and her mother. Best mother-daughter date ever!! The class was informative, hands-on, creative and most of all FUN!! Looking forward to checking out the other classes as well.

A MUST!. We went to tour the place when we found ourselves making what we love doing. We were having fun while learning. Just make sure you do the same when you visit Tokyo. This MUST be part of your itinerary! It's totally worth it! Trulu something you could bring home --> learning and experience! And something to look forward to when we go back this April!

"The Ideal Cultural Experience in Tokyo". I will highly recommend this class to anyone visiting Tokyo, the experience you can take from this class is absolutely priceless! The teachers were very knowledgeable, accommodating and enthusiastic, they knew everything about the food, ingredients and traditional, authentic cooking. Not the stuff that you see on cookbooks. Lastly the school were less than an minute away from bus stops and 2 major train lines. so if your a tourist in Japan wondering were to spend your R and R, visit and join Arigato Japan Cooking Classes & Food Tours. Me and my family really enjoyed the class- the highlight of our Tokyo trip !

Something maki!. California maki is my favorite! And learning to prepare it gives me a worthwhile experience... I definitely had so much! Will recommend Arigato Japan to all my friends in the Philippines! love it and will surely be back!

Unique Japan experience when in Tokyo!. I thought that making sushi would be hard but it's actually easy and fun at the same time.. If you are visiting Tokyo, you might want to make time for an Arigato Japan class. The Japanese instructors were very warm and accommodating too! P.S. Their Food Tour was so informative & fun as well! I learned so much!

Authentic JAPANESE FOOD Trip!. This is a highly recommended class if you want to have a cultural experience! Me and my sister took this class and it was absolutely fun and informative. They told us information about Japanese Sushi and other trivia that we never knew before. Amazing teachers , great location and very clean atmosphere! Highly recommended!!!

Fun way to learn how to cook!. As someone who has lived in Japan for a while, I've had a hard time finding a cooking school that teaches in English. This place was very nice and clean, was conveniently located, and had professional staff. The dishes were great and taught in a simple and fun way. I'll definitely be able to refer back to what I learned how to make and make it myself now. I hope to return to do the walking food tour next. Definitely add this to your to-do list in Tokyo if you haven't already!

Sushi course. If you want to experience in Tokyo something that you can take home with you and enjoy later on, this is something I can recommend. Very friendly teachers who spoke fluent English and knew exactly how to make perfect sushi. A wonderful experience!

An excellent enjoyable activity to learn when in Tokyo. My wife and I arrived a few days before the Tokyo Marathon. As we were preparing our TO DO list, we learned about and were so happy we attended the Arigato Japan cooking school... specifically the Sushi Course. The course was taught in perfect english! Not only did we learn the history of sushi but also learned how to make our own colorful and yummy creations as well. The class started at 10:30 and the time was just right to learn, make and eat our lunch : ) This is also the carbo load needed to run the Tokyo Marathon! We also met some new friends in our class. I would like to thank and congratulate Anne for putting up such a school. It was such a fun enjoyable learning experience! I would also highly recommend Tourists who visit Japan to enroll and attend the quick, easy and FUN cooking classes available at Arigato Japan!

Fun and Informative!. My husband and I attended the sushi-making class yesterday morning. I never expected that creating fancy-looking sushi could be that easy and satisfying! Our teachers were top-notch "chefs" in their own right, having cooked for their families for a long time. They were well-versed in English and clearly explained the step-by-step process of cooking the soup, preparing the rice for the sushi, and eventually putting the sushi together in an artistic manner. The best part was that we got to EAT what we made and they were delicious! We also met some wonderful people who belong to the international community and a few locals. Indeed, this was half a day well-spent! Thank you Arigato Japan!

Excellent!. I did the Udon cooking class and it was just amazing! You learn a lot while having fun at the same time. Ayuko speaks perfect English, which is a must! I highly recommend this activity to all interested in Japanese food and cooking. Plus the setting was cozy, and the other participants really cool people!

Bento class - fantastic!. This class was the highlight of my trip to Tokyo. I have only been home a couple of weeks but I have already used the techniques that I learned in your class. It has also inspired me to explore more Japanese cuisine. I totally recommend Buddha Bellies Cooking School to anyone traveling to Tokyo...what better way to learn about a culture, than through food. Such a great experience!

My favorite souvenir. Regular class schedule and website made booking and payment in advance easy (I booked about 10 days in advance, so relatively spontaneous booking is possible!). Location was easy to find and right next to the Metro exit. The Udon-class itself was wonderful: Small group, nice atmosphere, host speaks fluent English and everything is well-prepared. Cooking was really fun and the outcome was delicous. I especially liked that we received the recipes afterwards with information on how to get the right ingredients back at home, so it's easy to cook everything authentically at home.Price is definitely a fair deal for this high-quality experience. Wonderful!I'll be back for another class on my next visit to Tokyo for sure!

Fun local experience!. My husband and I had so much fun at Ayuko's cooking class, making traditional Japanese food. She explained everything very clearly and had helped us when it was our turn to make the food. Afterwards, we had a lovely meal with our classmates and Ayuko. Definitely recommend this cooking class for anyone that was a local cooking experience.

Sushi class. I must say my experience from this class was amazing. You learn the most when the class is hands on and lucky for me this time of the year was not a busy time of the year therefore I had almost one on one guidance. I was very impressed with Ayuko-san's knowledge and the ability to share her knowledge in perfect English. She has credibility and credentials as a bonafide chef and I was very lucky to find her. Most of all, she is very generous with her time to answer any questions about any art of Japanese cooking.I hope to sign up for another class with her when I return to Japan.

Washogu cooking. I was absolutely satisfied with this cooking school. I learned a lot of new important things and techniques and the washogu on the end was amazing. The course came up to expectations. I recommend!

Amazing Bento Cooking Class. I had amazing time with Ayuko and her small intimate class. She was very knowledgeable of Japanese cuisine and gave great guidance and suggestions. She mentioned the Kappa area, full of kitchen supplies and directed me on how to get there via train. It was easy to book the lesson via email and she was courteous to food allergies/dietary preferences. This is a great way for a foodie to really embrace Japanese culture and cuisine from a local. I'll definitely take her class again!

Wagashi class. We enjoyed the Buddha Bellies wagashi class. The instructor did a great job breaking down the steps for us and being patient as we did them ourselves. I was skeptical about our wagashi coming out as nice as the ones I saw in pictures, but they came out looking great! We made 4 wagashi that were put in a very nice container and box to take with us. At the end of the class, we were served a wagashi and cup of matcha tea. I would definitely recommend this class to others.

Honeymoon trip activity - success!. My wife and I came as part of our honeymoon week in Tokyo. The instructor was excellent, the location right next to the metro station and the food was superb. Her style allows you to make your own dish but in a guaranteed-to-be-delicious way. She also shared a lot about Japanese culture and cooking tips for how we can recreate this back home. I highly recommend this fun and satisfying activity if you're in Tokyo!

Great way to learn about japanese cooking. We attended a sushi class with our teenage children and everybody loved it. Everything was explained and demonstrated in perfect English. The class was held in a beautiful and clean room. The sushi tasted great and so did the sake.

Very nice host and a lot of information. It was a wish of mine to come to Tokyo and do a classic Sushi Class. We enjoyed the day and learned a lot. The lesson could have taken longer (learning how to cook the rice for example, as it never works at home - without a rice cooker; and maybe also learn about California Rolls) but it was worth the money and we had a great time and a lot of fun!

Excellent choice for an experience learning about Japanese cooking. I really wanted to learn more about cooking in Japan so after applying to a number of places- got a quick response from Buddha Bellies. It was a GREAT choice! Our teacher Ayuko was professional, well organized, clear and her English is excellent. We made homemade Udon noodles, Teriyaki chicken and Spinach salad with Gomai sauce. It was all delicious and easy to make. Ayuko also offered a very special bonus of homemade Plum wine or juice- This is what "foodies" dream about. She provided the recipes and is available for further advice (after I forgot something when I got home). The studio is compact but charming and filled with enticing books on cooking, gardening and Japanese culture. I highly recommend the experience!!

A really great way to spend a day in Tokyo. I love Japanese food so on my first trip to Japan I decided to take a cooking class. I enjoyed it so much that I also did a second one! Ayuko is a great teacher who is very patient and an expert chef. The class sizes were small and it was an opportunity to make new friends from all around the world :)My first class was on making a bento box which was so impressive and delicious. The second class was on decorative sushi. I couldnt believe how well they turned out!The class is really easy to find and get to on the subway. I definitely plan to take another class next time I'm in Tokyo!

Excellent cooking class. My husband and I had a fantastic time learning how to cook a Washoku (a traditional Japanese three dish meal + soup). Ayuko is a great host and professional cook. She took to the time to explain all the dishes and their cultural significance. The meal was DELICIOUS! We would definitely recommend this class if you go to Tokyo. Definitely a good cultural experience.

Best cooking classes ever!. Cooking with Ayuko was amazing! I joined a sushi class and I enjoyed so much the method and class ambience that I decided to join the rest of lessons and menus available.Highly recommended!

Awesome class. My husband and I have this thing that wherever we go, we take a cooking class. This class was epic: Ayuko is a lovely, prepared, skilled and fantastic chef and host. She explained and demonstrated every recipe and every detail, she gave us tips and tricks on how to prepare the best sushi and her English is superb!My husband and I had a fantastic time! Thanks a lot and I hope to come to visit Japan again and attend another one of your classes!
Excellent teacher!!!. Had an amazing experience. Great for beginners, and really informative. Nice and cozy and an excellent experience with people sharing and getting to know each other.
great beginner to sushi making!. loved the class - the teacher was very patient and thoughtfully answered all of our questions. was a fantastic beginning into the art of sushi making.

Great and informative sushi-making class on short notice. During our 4-week stay in Japan, we experienced a lot of fantastic things, from experiencing the full glory of sakura season, learning how to make traditional Japanese sweets in Yugawara, and scoring a cooking class at Buddha Bellies on short notice during our 5 days in Tokyo. We had failed to plan ahead sufficiently and emailed Ayuko on short notice to inquire about any classes. Knowing how busy she was, I was impressed with how quickly she responded and arranged a sushi-making class for the next day. The price was very reasonable, class size was small and intimate, the space was comfortable and brimming with books, and all ingredients and equipment was provided. She provided a nice encapsulation of the history of sushi and the different types of sushi. As well, she entertained some of our random questions. You really appreciate how hard it is to make sushi after taking Ayuko's class. None of us could manage to properly grab a handful of sushi rice without using gloves. Even making a roll was tricky but she patiently walked us through the techniques. Being able to enjoy the fruits of our labor, even if it didn't look as beautiful as sushi you'd get in a restaurant, was great fun, accompanied by either beer or sake and a little sweet. The parting gift of the printed recipe and the bamboo sushi roller topped off the visit. If your Japanese is nonexistent/terrible, thereby necessitating a class in English, and you want to take a cooking class, Ayuko is the person to go to. Not only is she a consummate professional, but you have plenty of options of classes to choose from! I only wish we had more time to check out some other classes. The next time in Tokyo we hope to drop in again and I highly recommend Buddha Bellies if you're thinking of taking a class.
A pleasant experience unique and challenging learning. The training was patient and good attitude we have made the event one of the more pleasant experiences that our Tokyo

A nice traditional meal with Ayuko. We had a really nice time with Ayuko. The washoku class was very interesting and tasty. Ayuko took time to explain the importance of every element of the meal, and was a great sensei. I especially liked the dashi-tamago roll. Also, there was a TV crew that record the class for a news show. It was really fun to be interviewed. We recommend this class and will probably take an other one during a future trip!

Ayuko was patient and a great teacher. We signed up for the fish cutting and sushi making class. Ayuko was a patient and great, fun teacher. She showed us the proper way to cut and did multiple demonstrations. It was a fun, interactive class - and then we got to eat it afterwards. Yummy and highly recommended!

Very interesting and easy to follow. I did the sushi and fish cutting course and both were fantastic, I would really recommend doing both courses together for a more in-depth sushi course this is the quick, fun and (not so) easy way to learn to make proper sushi.

Amazing. By far the best sushi making class. An amazing experience and a must try in Tokyo. Only English speaking class run by the nicest, kindest and most friendly chef who is one of the best chefs in Asia. Don't hesitate... BOOK NOW..

A New Meaning to "Fish Fingers". I signed up for the 12,000JPY fish-cutting class, which was pretty intimate because there were only 2 students so we really got focused attention. Ayuko really took us through the nitty gritty of expertly cutting and gutting fish... and we used the fresh fillets for the sushi class straight after. We were joined by two more students and got a hands-on experience in making rice and creating lovely sushi, which we ate for lunch with sparkling wine. Ayuko answered all our questions and was very happy to take lots of photos of the group. The place was small but cozy and easy to find from the train station. All in all a very satisfying experience.

Sushi and sake heaven. I highly recommend the sushi making course. The teacher was excellent and very patient. Don't underestimate how difficult it is to make nigiri! It was all taught in English and we were also given the recipe so we can make it again at home. The best bit of course though was getting to eat it all at the end. Delicious!

Better than we could have hoped for. We did the fish cutting and sushi making class. Our instructor, Ayuko, was amazing, as was the class. We learned all about how to cut a fish from the start, make maki, and nigiri, as well as a brief history of sushi. We were then able to enjoy what we made (it was so much food that most people couldn't finish) along with a nice glass of plum sake. Before leaving, we were all given a gift too. This is a must do class.

Perfect way to immerse into Japane cuisine and culture!. I am so grateful I participated in this lovely Washoku workshop. It was a rainy day in Tokyo, so timing was perfect, but even with a sunny day I would not regret. Ayuko responded to my very last minute booking request super fast and the next day I was sitting in her class with three other great people. She picked us up at the train station, introduced us to Japanese cooking and dining. We cooked, tasted, sniffed, and ate, we laughed and had really good times. After the class, Ayuko gave us enough time to enjoy our creations and ask all possible questions not only about Japanese food. I really enjoyed her wonderful book collection and even bought a handy little book on Japanese culture. Ayuko was very kind and helped me figure out a perfect walk in the area, suggested spots to visit and even made a call to a museum to see if it was opened which saved me a ride across the entire Tokyo as the museum was closed. I will happily come back for another cooking class once I am in Tokyo again.

Amazing experience in Umami heaven. I was fortunate enough to come across Buddha bellies cooking school during my stay in Tokyo. As a chef myself i am always looking to learn new things. My teacher Ayuko was extremely professional and knowledgeable in Japanese cuisine and had me making some of my favorite dishes in no time. Her experience with sake and food and sake pairing was also a bonus. For anyone visiting Tokyo wanting to learn anything from sushi to tempura, Buddha Bellies Cooking School is a must visit!

Perfect way to learn how to make sushi!. Ayuko, does a great job at making this a very well organized and enjoyable class! The directions to the meeting place were easy to follow and the space we used was comfortable and clean. There were only 6 of us in the sushi making class and we were all kept busy the whole time. The sushi making instructions were clear and non intimidating- it was almost a shame to have to eat our creations! Overall, it was a wonderful experience and an excellent way to give your feet a break from all the exploring in Tokyo!
A great experience.. We did learn a lot, and got to keep the recipes. This cooking school was a great experience and I'm glad we did it.

Fantastic class, lovely teacher and delicious sushi. Highly recommended!. I attended the fish cutting and sushi class and had a wonderful experience. Ayuko was a fantastic teacher. She was very patient, encouraging and informative. I learnt a lot and really enjoyed the experience. It exceeded my expectations. I would highly recommend the class!

Great class with a friendly teacher. We've booked the 'everyday' cooking class and it was spot on. Good array of dishes with a friendly chef explaining the process. We've got some insights into the ingredients, preparation process and presentation. All in all - I'd recommend a class.

Lovely and informative Bento box lesson! Highly recommended. What a lovely morning spent learning how to make our own bento boxes - informative, fun and open, plus we got the recipes to take home with us. I only wish we'd had our class before we went to see the Tsujiki fish market, as I probably would have picked up some ingredients to take home and put into practice in my own kitchen! Will have to find a good source here in the UK :)(NB we weren't really a family with teens but a family of adults!)

Great experience in Japanese Food!. Thank you so much for your lesson - it was a great experience to cook Sushi! I've joined with my business guests as they are all familiar with EATING part, they all enjoyed MAKING sushi so much!

Intimate. it was a lovely class. Chef Ayuko makes you feel at ease right away and it is a very intimate class in a small environment. Very good technique, that you can't learn through youtube! The amount of sushi made will satisfy your appetite. Thank you for a great time Ayuko!- Anna

Amazing Fun. We took the sushi / fish filleting and cutting class with Ayuko. It was extremely fun and let's just Ayuko was very patient with me during the fish cutting session of the class. Definitely a must do if you love food!

Edible education!. The highlight of our trip to Japan! Ayuko's class was a very enjoyable and insightful. We learnt a brief history of sushi, followed by a session of making edomae, or Tokyo style sushi. Ayuko is a lovely person and brilliant teacher, her class is a must for all sushi-lovers!
Great experience. We had so much fun in the sushi making class. The instructor was so helpful and the sushi we made was really tasty

Delicious fun!. My parents were visiting me in Tokyo from the U.S. and looking for activities other than sightseeing. We all enjoy cooking (and eating!)- so a cooking class was a perfect fit. Before even attending, I could tell Ayuko of Buddha Bellies was the best! I was not wrong. We signed up for the decorative sushi class and had a great experience. We enjoyed meeting and talking with Ayuko and our classmates while learning to make beautiful designs in our sushi. I look forward to taking another class with Ayuko.

Wonderful experience. Ayuko's cooking class was a highlight of our trip to Japan. We learnt ramen and teriyaki chicken recipes. The recipes were easy to learn and the food was very tasty and I will definitely make them again now that I'm home. Ayuko herself was a lovely person and really seemed to enjoy sharing her recipes with us which really made it an amazing experience.

Authentic Japanese Cuisine. Ayuko is an excellent teacher, friendly, easy to understand and very helpful. I have a very comfortable time with the cooking class. The dishes are very authentic Japanese and great looking. It's a must come back place when I'm back to Tokyo to learn new Japanese dish. :):):)

Nice experience with room for improvement. We took the sushi course at Buddha Bellies and found it very useful and interesting. But we didn't like two things: 1) the course lasted only 1h30 and not 2h-2h30 as stated on the website and at the end of the course we felt kindly encouraged to leave, although we still had questions and some beer in our glasses. 2) The printed recipes of what we did during the course, that we received at the end, were not complete. The rolls, the most difficult part of the course, were not included. I emailed the school to ask for the recipe, but received no reply. Not very professional, especially as they encourage you not to take notes during the course because 'you will receive later all the printed information on what you did'...

Top-Notch Sushi Class!. Ayuko's cooking class was a wonderful, educational, and delicious experience! Ayuko is a great teacher, taking time to inform us about Japanese history and culture throughout the class. She is a very skilled chef and a kind and patient instructor. The class includes a giant (self-made) meal, ample sake, and wonderful company. It was a great opportunity to meet other visitors who were also interested in learning about the sushi making process. In addition to the class, Ayuko recommended a wonderful restaurant and helped us make a reservation since our Japanese is, well, poor. I HIGHLY recommend this class to anyone looking to dig deeper into Japanese culture during their Tokyo travels, it was exactly what I was hoping it would be!

Sushi, Sake and a 素敵な先生. This was a fantastic class and a unique and fun way to explore another side of Japanese culture. In our class we learned how to make sushi, miso and gyouza. Not only was Ayuko very good at instructing us on the techniques, she also gave us so much interesting background as to why things were done the way they were. It was fascinating to learn how Tokyo's samurai culture had influenced sushi compared to the more artistic Kyoto. We also got to see (and feel!) the hardest food in the world! The yuzu sake we sampled was amazing as well. Overall I highly recommend the class. Ayuko is a fabulous instructor and does an amazing job of making it a very personal and educational experience! We had a blast!

Very satisfied with sushi lesson!!! . Such a very good cooking class and very nice teacher!!! Now i can make real nigiri sushi for my family and friends. I really love japanese cuisine especially yours Hope to see you again in the next cooking class. Thank you so much miss Ayuko

I learned so much!. I have taken several of Ayuko's cooking classes. She has taught me to make delicious gyoza, sukiyaki and multiple kinds of sushi, as well as how to cut and fillet a whole fish. On top of what she's taught me about food, she is also a sake sommelier and has taught me pretty much everything I know about sake. She is a friendly, patient and very knowledgeable instructor who enjoys sharing Japanese culture and food with others. I would recommend her classes to anyone who enjoys cooking and wants to learn more about how to make Japanese food — the hardest part is choosing which class to take!

Lovely time learning how to make a Japanese bento box. Well structured, informative and taught in English which is always helpful. In learning how to make the bento box, we also learnt how to make dashi and tempura amongst 2 other dishes.

Bento Box .... Ayuko was a fantastic teacher. My husband and I attended her Bento Box class. I am the cook in our house and it was a great experience for my husband who achieved great success with his cooking and construction of the bento box. We have made this since we have arrived back home. Travel is extremely easy, as it is right next to the exit of the railway station.
sushi. Ayuko is a great teacher!I experienced nigiri sushi lesson.  I tried  at home with my kids and their friends.We enjoyed it very much!

Fantastic experience. Ayuko is a great teacher. I did the washoku class, which was fun and informal. We made a variety of dishes including teriyaki pork/fish, miso soup, a chicken and rice dish, a salad with dressing and a mushroom side. We also got to try sake. There were7 of us in the class, which was the perfect number. We loved the cooking, the learning and getting to know other people in the class. You also get a gift at the end!Ayuko met us outside the subway station and took us up to the kitchen, which was 1 minute away. The location was fine - we didn't explore the area but the Tokyo subway is so easy and quick to use, there's no problems getting there.When I was choosing a cooking school/class, I found that the prices were all pretty much the same, so this one is on par with others and completely worth it.

Great little piece of Japan to take home. I've made my bento again since getting home and it was great!I'd definitely recommend this to anyone interested in continuing their Japan adventure even after you've left.

Great Japanese cooking class with wonderful instructor and assistant!. We had a blast with Ayuko and her assistant, Ai. We took the bento box course and learned how to make tamago, chicken teriyaki, and a cucumber-seaweed salad. The course ended up being just the two of us, which was quite nice. Ayuko and her assistant were extremely friendly and patient, and it was so nice to learn how to make some of our favorite Japanese staples. This is a great activity for couples, friends, and anyone looking to experience a little bit of Japanese food and culture. Highly recommend!

Nothing special. We did the Washoku lesson and were underwhelmed.We were 5 people and cooked a bowl of rice, meat and egg, teriaki fish, miso soup and some veggies. We were asked to start at 9 am instead of 11 am because of some problems with the location. This itself was not a problem for us, but we had the impression that our teacher was very hectic and we we were a burden even though she was nice. Maybe she was hectic because she had someone come in to fix the air conditioner (which was the reason why we were asked to come earlier) but I think as a customer we can still expect good service. We did get a package of miso paste to compensate for the inconvenience of coming earlier but would have liked a relaxed teacher more. The food we cooked was nothing special. I think people who go for cooking classes like cooking and know the basics about it, so it is not unusual to expect something special when you go for such a class. The food we cooked was good but not something we couldn't have managed with a good cookbook. The only really interesting thing was making the dashi and learning about the different ingredients, but here we had to ask what the different things were, because our teacher assumed we already knew.When it came to eating the food, our teacher went into the kitchen and cleaned up instead of sitting and chatting with us, which would have been the perfect opportunity to share some special knowledge about Japanese cuisine. All in all, we were dissappointed with what we experienced and are sorry to say that we cannot recommend this to people who like cooking and know their way around a kitchen.

Great experience and veggie friendly!. A friend and I attended a cooking class with Ayuko in June and had an amazing time! She is very thorough and clear and she had a very nice classroom and it was very easy to find. She also gave us some interesting background on sushi. I really appreciated her accommodating my vegetarian diet. She had other ingredients and ideas for me which was great! Highly recommended for your Tokyo visit!

Great beginner class with an awesome instructor!. I'm a beginning to intermediate chef who cooks for fun at home. I took two classes at Buddha Bellies: a bento box class and a fish cutting class. Ayuko, who runs the class, is an extremely good teacher who gives clear instructions and can answer questions about the methodology behind her recipes. Her English is extremely good, as she has also spent time teaching English in Japanese schools.When the fish cutting class that I had originally signed up for was cancelled, Ayuko went out of her way to find another time that would work and gave me a private lesson in fish cutting. I have since purchased and read a few books about Japanese knives and proper techniques for cutting fish and am super appreciative of Ayuko teaching me the sanmae oroshi technique, which I feel I would never have completely understood from reading books.Ayuko went out of her way to make my experience awesome, and packed me a sushi dinner from the fish I had cut at the end of our class for me to take to the airport. I nearly missed my flight because I was still making sushi in her class, but based on the quality of the instruction I feel that the risk was well worth it.

Our first evening in Tokyo was amazing!. I arrived with my husband in Tokyo the same day, so Ayuko sushi class was our very first experience in Japan. We loved it.We're great sushi lovers, so we were convinced to know a lot about it, but we didn't really.The class is in a tiny room and the atmosphere is very warm. Ayuko is graduated in English language and her English is perfect. She taught us how to prepare the nigiri and the rolls, but also a lot about the sushi, the tea ceremony and many other interesting facts. The only problem is we can't go now to the most of the sushi restaurants in Europe and USA, because she made us fussy about the Japanese food.I highly recommend her classes. The next time we go to Tokyo we'll take her fish cutting class.

Foodietastic!!. What a fantastic experience, cooking at Buddha Bellies with the lovely Ayuko. The three dishes were described and explained to us before starting. We were given the ingredients and followed Ayuko's step by step guide on what to do.After preparing the ingredients we got cooking and then sat down to enjoy our delicious food - oishi!!The class catered well for all - adults as well as children. Everyone thoroughly enjoyed themselves.I would definitely recommend this class to anyone wishing to have as many different Japanese experiences on their visit.
Great Class. Buddha bellies cooking class was really great, Ayuko explained things clearly & in detail. The food was excellent, looking forwards to making it at home!
Bento box. Very nice cooking class.Learned a lot about cooking Japanese. Ayuko was a great teacher and also nice cooking mates.Katarina from Sweden

That was so much fun. We went there to take the washoku class. That is 3 little meals and miso soup. Not only did we learn how to cook, but we also found out a lot about the traditon of japanese food. Everyone was super friendly. The ingredients were first class and the food was delicious (i was surprised i was able to cook something so yummy... :P ) the atmosphere is very warm and the kitchen is clean. i also loved how you can also buy books of all sorts. Definitely worth taking a class!!!

One of the Highlights of our visit to Tokyo, fun and educational. My family, 2 adults and 2 children ages 10 and 12, participated in a full day of classes at Buddha Bellies Cooking School during our visit to Tokyo in June, 2015.
