We all loved these classes and recommend them highly. We took three classes in one day, in the following order: 1. Fish Cutting, 2. Sushi Preparation, 3. Cooking Chicken Teriyaki with homemade Udon noodles.I recommend the third class if you have younger children. The first two classes do require dexterity, concentration and care since students use large, extremely sharp traditional knives. But if your children are ready for it, as mine were, all of these classes were awesome.The host teacher, Ayuki, is truly a great teacher and highly skilled chef. Furthermore, she is fluent in English and also provided a written set of instructions in English to take home. She encouraged us to take pictures as we performed the tasks so that we wouldn't forget any of the steps.There is also a small but very good library/bookstore where you can read (during class breaks) about other artistic and creative aspects of Japanese culture that might appeal to you, such as traditional carpentry, in addition to the many cookbooks.In summary, this was a highlight of our visit to Tokyo.

Amazing class - insightful, fun and delicious!. I don't think words can adequately describe how much fun this was! A friend and I took part in a wagashi (Japanese sweets) class where we made nerikiri, a really beautiful sweet made from white and red bean paste. I am passionate about food but have absolutely no technical skills when it comes to cooking.... However, by the end of the class I had created intricate and stunning hydrangea-like sweets!The process is delicate but Ayuko explains and demonstrates everything very clearly, as well as clearly laying out all the materials and ingredients. She was such a friendly and relaxed teacher that even when I coated myself AND the table AND the floor in bean paste, I didn't feel too embarrassed. She is so knowledgable so be sure to ask her lots of questions about the history of the food and about her cooking experience. She knows a lot about sake, for example... Really, don't think twice about booking a Buddha Bellies class. Cooking/cuisine is a great insight into a culture, and Ayuko is a fantastic guide as well as a chef/teacher!

Traditional cooking class!. This is a great experience for those who want to take home a piece of Japan. The host accommodated the meal for dietary requirements and was extremely friendly and knowledgable. I recommend doing a cooking class as it helps ease some of the stress that comes along with visiting busy cities! Thank you!

Short Sushi-Making Class. It was a 2-3 hour sushi making class that covered the basic methods of making sushi (keep in mind that sushi masters learn for years!), as well as some history about the cuisine. You make your own sushi, which you then each for lunch! The instructor spoke English well and was very engaging. The class was also a great way to meet new people, especially fellow travelers.

Amazing class and teacher!. We had a fantastic time in Ayuko's sushi class! It was an intimate setting that allowed for a lot of individualized attention. Ayuko has a teaching style that is relaxed, informative and fun. This was definitely one if the highlights of our visit and would absolutely recommend Buddha Bellies to anyone planning a trip to Tokyo!

Accomedated for Hallal needs. Such a great experience with a great instructor. Learning about the history and traditions of sushi was a great addition to getting to eat all our wonderful creations. The instructor was very friendly and spoke fluent english making it a more pleasurable and enjoyable experience. She was also able accommodated for our halal needs. A great way to end our stay in japan. I highly recommend this class if you are visiting Japan.

We had a blast!!!. I attended Art sushi class with my friend. It was absolutely amazing experience and great learning of different culture. I would super recommend to the all tourist who are visiting Japan to be able to get new experience and excitement! Thanks to the instructor, Ayuko, who was really nice to us and gave us the excellent explanation during the class. We had a blast!!!

The BEST Class I ever had!. My friend and I took a Sake and decorative sushi class and enjoyed much more than expected.The instructor, Ayuko speaks fluent English with humor and has a lot of knowledge of Japanese food. We tasted 6 types of Sake at the class.We learned the differences and the making process of each Sake. That was worth of choosing a souvenir for my family.As for decorative sushi, we created it by ourselves after a demonstration by Ayuko. It was a little bit difficult, but well done with her good advice.That was a great learning experience.
Wagashi Class. My friends and I attended the wagashi class. Azuko-San explains very well and she made the class fun. I really enjoyed her classes.

A successful event!. We recently held a workshop-style event with clients at which Ayuko taught us to make decorative sushi. There were 24 participants and everyone really enjoyed the event. The class was well-structured, with a short presentation about the history of sushi, followed by a demonstration by Ayuko and then we all had the chance to get creative and make our own decorative sushi rolls! There was even a competitive element as Ayuko chose the best creations. At the end we enjoyed the results of our hard work. The class was very professionally organised, and Ayuko and her assistants did a fantastic job preparing and clearing everything away afterwards. We would be delighted to book another event with Buddha Bellies in the future, and would certainly recommend their classes.

Cozy, clean, convenient!. I took a Sushi class and it was great fun to make my own Sushi! The studio is not large but cozy with the classy design. The building is just beside a station, so very easy to access. Thanks to Ayuko's expert teaching, I enjoyed everything and highly recommend to join! Ingredients are fresh and excellent explanation to retry at home is provided.

LOVED our washoku class!. I filled out the online form and chose the washoku (traditional Japanese) course to trying during my short, but incredibly fun adventure to Tokyo. I have taken other cooking courses before, but this has been by far the best! Although it did seem at first a little expensive (~$65 for myself), I think it was worth it - loved the small class atmosphere, meeting other friendly travelers to Japan, and learning more about authentic Japanese cuisine!

Great afternoon Sushi Session. What a delightful few hours learning all about Japanese Sushi. Coming from Canada it is all about rolls and wasabi for me. It was great to spend the time learning about the type of rice and cooking method. Who knew there was sugar and vinegar in the rice? Great afternoon and the bonus was eating the sushi with a glass of saki. Great way to end up our stay in Japan. We will hopefully be taking this method home and making some ourselves!

Great class; great food; great fun. We were part of a six person class to learn about sushi; learn how to make it; and then ate what we made. It was perfect for our last full day in Tokyo. Ayuko is the instructor's name. It was interesting to learn about various ways to make sushi. Highly recommend!

Do this class!. My husband and I took a combined fish cutting, nigiri and art sushi course. We have taken a number of cooking courses in various countries, including several others in Japan and would easily say this is one of the best experiences we have had! Ayuko is very knowledgeable and will not only teach you the sushi making process, but educate you on sushi's history and regional variations. Amazing experience - you won't find anything better.

FISH CUTTING OK, SUSHI MAKING GOOD EXPERIENCE. Ayuko was our instructor for both the fish cutting and sushi making classes. The one major problem we had was that we booked early and understood we were the only two people for the 'personal' fish cutting lesson. Much to our surprise, another person showed up and had a negative impact on what could have been a great experience - there were only 2 cutting boards and knives and he hogged them both, actually complaining that Ayuko needed to get another cutting board/knife set. Ayuko should have gone for quality of instruction vs quantity of money.Ayuko is a professionally trained sushi expert and she shares her knowledge of Japan and sushi easily. While we have made sushi at home before, it was a good 'refresher' for us. There was not really any 'cooking' as she essentially prepared everything ahead of time (sliced fish, rice, etc.) - all you have to do is form the sushi.So compared to other actual cooking experiences, the actual cooking part was short and sweet, with little 'adult beverages', taught by a very friendly sushi expert. Once will be enough for us.

Great learning experience taught by a passionate, friendly teacher.. Ayuko's cooking class was highly recommended to us by a friend (and according to every search engine and tripadvisor review I read), my girlfriend and I have been wanting to learn how to make our own sushi for years and we finally took the plunge. At 40 GBP a head, you might consider that expensive, however, based on the quality of ingredients we were provided with alone, in addition to Ayuko's friendly, expert teaching we well worth it!The class is right beside a subway station and is very accessible and easy to reach, Ayuko shared her passion for Japanese cuisine and the two hours were some of the most memorable we spent in Tokyo.Just make sure you come to the class hungry and I'd highly recommend the Plum Sake as a drink of choice!Thanks again Ayuko!

Great learning experience. Great learning experience, we were all given the recipes afterwards and a special free gift! Things mentioned in the bad reviews have been solved, the woman who runs the class now has someone to help so the helper takes care of the washing up and also the class was a good size, not to small to feel intimidated and not too large, so we all got attention from the host. Will definitely be trying to make these at home soon!

Enjoyable Cooking Class!. On a recent trip to Tokyo I took a few friends to Ayuko's cooking class. We learned some new dishes and had a wonderful time. Ayuko is a great teacher, she is both fun and knowledgeable. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend her cooking school to anyone looking for such an experience. It was easy to sign up and pay for the class online. Ayuko accomodated our request for out of the ordinary timing and gave us easy directions on how to find her location.

Great experience!. Took the washoku class with my sister who was visiting me in Tokyo. We had so much fun and really enjoyed our meal... It was a great way to spend our afternoon and it was one of our best meals we shared together! Ayuko is a great instructor. Can't wait to try another one of her classes.

Great experience !!!. After travelling for almost 3 weeks in Japan and trying all the amazing food, it was great at the end to go on a sushi course and learn how to make it finally. Great course, great food, people and teacher!!!

Great class. My friend and I took part in the decorative sushi class. We had a great time and learnt a lot about different ingredients and how to make different types of sushi. Our host Ayuko was lovely and would highly recommend to others
Great food, and environment.. Went solo to this class, and I know now why it's so hard to book. Very friendly instructor, cozy space, and great all around experience. Must try if you visit Japan.

Great experience. I took the sweet making course on April 6th and enjoyed it. The atmosphere was relaxing with a homely vibe to it. Our teacher Ayuko was very friendly and spoke very good English.
Oh and the results were delicious! Highly recommended.

Fantastic!. What a fantastic class! Fun, educational and, most of all, tasty! We were all amazed at what we achieved thanks to the teacher and will definitely be trying out the skills we learnt in the future.

Buddha Bellies Washoku Class. My husband and I took part in one of Buddha Bellies Washoku cooking classes during our trip to Japan. We thoroughly enjoyed the experience and would highly recommend this as a way to gain a better understanding of Japanese cooking in a relaxed and friendly environment! And the best bit is eating all the delicious food that you have created!

Super sushi session. A really interesting and fun class. The two hours flew by, and the sushi was delicious (if I don't say so myself). Defintely recommend for the sushi beginner. Also, Ayuko was a great host and instructor

A fun cooking class. My fiancé and I took part in the okinomiyaki class and really enjoyed it. The class size is perfect and it's very hands on.
I would definitely recommend the okinomikyaki class as it is something that I have been able to recreate easily here in England.

Great Experience for the Family. After visiting Japan for a number of times and seeing lots of temples and cherry blossoms, we were looking for something new to experience. The cooking class with Buddha Bellies was a great new experience for us as we haven't done anything like this as a family. The place was very easy to find and we started on time. No prior cooking experience required and no need to bring anything, all ingredients and materials are provided. We had a great time and are excited to try making sushi at home!

Sweets class on March 27th. I attended the Sweets class on March 27th. Ayuko contacted me by email prior to the class w/directions by metro. She's a wonderful, friendly, and kind teacher. Her class is located right next to the Jimbocho station. My classmates were from Finland, Germany, and the US - a very fun bunch. We learned to make mochi and put together a parfait. It was very simple and lots of fun. I'd definitely sign up for the washoku class next time.

Learn to make sushi at Buddha Bellies Cooking School in Tokyo. I took a class at Buddha Bellies with my teenage daughter and a friend. It was a wonderful way to spend an afternoon. The school is very easy to find. Ayuka greeted us near the station and walked us to the school. Ayuka gave easy to follow instructions and we were all delighted with our creations. I had made sushi at home in the past, but failed. Ayuka offered excellent suggestions on how to ensure success. I cannot wait to make sushi at home now and am confident I will succeed. The class was also a very welcome break from doing the tourist thing.

It is worth visiting. I visited the decorative sushi making class. It was a great experience. Our teacher, Ayuko was great. I was surprised how good my sushi at the end looked. I would definitely suggest it. It is funny, she explains and shows it very well and the result is amazing. The place is easy to arrive from tokyo central station. It is definitely worth visiting this class.
Great experience. It was a pleasure to two more about Japanese culture through this cookery lessons.I definitely recomend it!

Fantastic fish cutting and super sushi. what an amazing experience! Everyone must do this whilst in Japan.It is so easy to get to on the Tokyo metroAyuko the class instructor is so lovey and she guides you through the art of sushi making with perfect English and lovely Japanese culture.We also did the fish cutting class which was also fantastic.If you go to Japan you can not miss taking this classThank you Ayuko for a wonderful time

Great team building. I arranged an afternoon course on the Firday afternoon of our week long offsite in Tokyo. Was great fun, really enjoyable, a cosy setting and environment, and really educational too. Perfect end to the week. Thankyou very much!Tim

One of my favorite experiences in Tokyo!. My girlfriend and I took the sushi making class based on previous reviews. Completely exceeded our expectations. The class was informative, personal, fun, and of course delicious! I would highly recommend to anyone visiting Tokyo.
Udon and Teriyaki Chicken Course. This course was lots of fun. We learnt an interesting method for kneading dough to make our Udon noodles! The food was delicious and instruction was excellent.

Amazing Japanese sweets class. My husband and I took the Japanese Sweets Class together. We were the only two in the class so we were able to have a lot of attention which was great. Ayuko is very well spoken and has a good grasp of culinary knowledge. She was really friendly and kind. We made mochi which was fun and would not have known how to make this otherwise. It was great to see mochi being sold around the markets after and knowing how exactly it was made! I definitely recommend this for anyone who is visiting Japan and would like to know more about Japanese cuisine.

Excellent fish cutting and sushi class. What to do in Japan but do a bit of sushi making!!! Unfortuantely I got very bad food poisoning the night before class so my husband went alone. But he had a fabulous time. The photos look amazing and he learnt alot about filleting fish. During this class they were filmed by a TV crew which was intimadating but exciting. I was very impressed with the pre-class commuication. Such a good experience in Tokyo. The host very generously gave a knife book, wasabi, rolling matts and nori for my husband to bring to back for me. A must for foodies.

Amazing fish cutting and sushi class!. My husband and I did the fish cutting and sushi class. Fish cutting was our favorite part. Auyko is a great teacher and explains everything so well. The kitchen is easy to get to off the subway and the room is full of interesting books. We thoroughly enjoyed our experience and would recommend it to anyone who is visiting Tokyo.

Great experience. My husband and I attended the sushi making class. Ayuko was an informative and patient teacher, especially when my "decorative" sushi didn't turn out to be very decorative at all! Her English is perfect so there were no problems with communication at all. We were filmed by Nippon TV which was a little distracting but we still really enjoyed the class.Best of all, you get to eat everything you made and it was delicious.A nice touch was getting the present of nori, chopsticks, wasabi and a sushi rolling mat to take home.Thanks Ayuko, it was a great experience. We'll be back to do another class next January.

Japanese knives and edomae sushi. Ayuko was very helpful from start to finish. Booking for a fish cutting and sushi class was a breeze. The cooking school was just close to Exit A2 of Jimbocho Station. And when we got there, the place was full of interesting books that we ended up buying a book on Japanese knives and another on edomae (Tokyo style) sushi. It was just me and my husband for the fish cutting class--we were to cut and fillet mackerel--and we enjoyed it tremendously learning about the basic techniques using a deba knife perfect for cutting and filleting fish, then a yanagiba knife for slicing sashimi. We were so impressed with the performance of Japanese knives that we went straight to Kamaasa in Kappabashi, as Ayuko recommended, after our class and bought ourselves a set each (for right handed left handed). Afterwards, we were joined by 6 others and we started with making the sushi rice. First, she taught us how to make a fancy sushi roll. Then next was the edomae sushi--how to form the rice in our hands and turn it into a shape of sushi, put wasabi, then form it again with tuna, salmon, mackerel, and squid. One of the students was vegetarian so he made an entirely different set--which by the way turned out very colourful and unique. Then, of course, the eating came next with sake or beer; we were so full by the time we finished. It wasn't the best sushi I ever ate in Tokyo, but it surely was the sweetest since I made it myself. =) Now my husband and I are so happy that we get to entertain at home serving sushi. Thank you, Ayuko!

Great finish to our japan trip. Spent 3 weeks travelling and tasting the delights of Japan ending up at Buddha Bellies and having our shot at Japanese cuisine. Guess what our family are having this weekend back in Australia???
Great food, awesome experience!. It was an awesome experience! Easy to follow, great food and totally delicious!! Ayuko is so friendly and welcoming, I would recommend it to anyone coming to Japan!!!

Interactive fun class!. I did the Bento box class with my 17 year old son. Ayuko is a warm and engaging host and explains and demonstrates everything very well. We learned to make Japanese rolled omelet, teriyaki chicken, Wakame and cucumber salad then arrange beautifully in a bento box. Lots of fun, and you can't quite believe as you sit down to lunch that you have actually made this exquisite looking and tasting meal yourself! Skills we will definitely be using back home! We went straight to kitchen street to purchase the special omelet pan so we can reproduce the same results back home! Thanks Ayuko for a great experience!

Do it!. I just knew about this course on the weekend and booked it one day before. The team responded quite quickly and I got place in bento box class for the next day, on Monday. Our mentor, Ayuko, was great, she explained clearly and made everyone at ease, the atmosphere was very friendly. There were 7 of us, we made our own egg rolls and the rest (wakame salad, decoration, chicken teriyaki) on team work. The course lasted about 2 hours. In the end, we ate our bento box along with our drinks preferences, whether it was sake, beer, or hot tea. Ayuko also served dessert and gave us a thoughtful gift in the end. It was nothing like professional cooking class, but I enjoyed it a lot. If you happen to be on holiday in Tokyo, just do it. It was so much fun!

Great fun, informative class.. I took the sushi making class: we made a fancy-looking sushi roll with egg and cucumber and some Nigirisushi (rice balls with sashimi on top). I learned a lot about sushi, about how to prepare and press the rice, and had an excellent (and super filling) meal afterwards. Lots of fun.

Udon and Teriyaki Chicken. Located right next to the A2 exit of Jimbocho station, Buddha Bellies cooking classes are held in a small library. Ayuko was our instructor and she was very friendly and clear. It's not a professional cooking set up by any means but it was fun to knead our own udon and to cook our own teriyaki chicken. Ayuko teaches several other classes and some of the larger more technical classes are held at a more professional location as she explained.The price for two of us was ¥15,120. The session goes for about 2.5 hours. Beer/sake/green tea is served with the food that you cooked. It was a fun experience and we definitely picked up some recipes that we will be making at home.

Thank you Ayuko. Our family of five attended the sushi making course. We learnt so much and made delicious sushi. Ayuko was so pleasant and informative. I would reccommend this experience if you are visiting Tokyo.

Fantastic cooking class in Tokyo. I did two classes with Budda Bellies, and loved both of them. I did the fish cutting/sashimi/decorative sushi class, and the udon and chicken teriyaki class. Both were small, with only a few participants, and Ayuko the teacher was wonderful. I would highly recommend this class to anyone who loves Japanese food, enjoys cooking, or simply wants to learn something new.Ayuko also gave us great advice on where to buy japanese chef's knives, and we loved the knives we ended up buying.

Great experience!. I attended one course on my own, and a second course on a subsequent trip. Recent reviews (great authentic cuisine, great instructor, small class size, comfortable environment) say it all. Makes the cuisine that much more accessible. It's a bargain and a fun time.David

Great, authentic Japanese cooking class!. Ayuko made our experience very enjoyable and authentic. She explained things really well and made us feel welcome into Japanese cuisine. The okonomiyaki we made was absolutely superb and I will definitely be making it as soon as I return home. This was my very first cooking class overseas and it has exceeded my expectations. Thank you for sharing your recipes.

Absolutely amazing experience. Highlight of my Tokyo trips.. I have actually taken 2 classes with buddha bellies. The first time the sushi cooking class and the second time a set meal class. The instructor is simply amazing. Not only is she a professionally trained chef and speaks perfect English, she is knowledgable, extremely nice and accomidating. I am vegan, and in a class of 7 or 8 people, I imagine it can be challenging to manage the one person that is making a different meal than everyone else's. But not only is Ayuko super nice about it, she even puts in extra thought to ensure that my experience and end result is just as good as the other participants. I cannot recommend buddha bellies enough.

Ayuko is a professional chef level cooking instructor. My wife and I enjoyed Ayuko's cooking class which was fun, educational, and created a wonderful meal. Ayuko showed us how to cook a typical Japanese meal using table top cooking appliances and assisted us going through each step if needed. She explained techniques to get the best results for everything from egg rolls to cooked fish and which products she prefers to use in cooking. She speaks excellent English and was very thorough answering our questions and clarifying technique. Ayuko's place was easy to find although we were staying over 15 miles away and took the subway. She has a small place which has only enough room for 6 students. We have taken cooking classes all over the world and this is one of our favorites - friendly, fun, quick, focused, and great results.

On of the best cooking classes in Tokyo. My daughter and I took a class over this past fall. We've taken cooking classes all over the world and this class stands out as one of our better experiences. It was fun, informative and hands on. In fact I am making plans to go back in a month with the rest of my family! Absolutely recommended!!

Experience that you will never forget. To experience a genuine native cooking experience in Japan, it's probably not that hard to find a very good company that will give you a great insight and delicious dishes. However, Ayuko at Buddha bellies creates such a homely and welcoming atmosphere you feel you have been learning from her for years. Small class and excellent tuition (in perfect English), it was well worth the money. A highlight of our trip and would book again on another visit.

Sushi making in a library. A great way to enjoy your own sushi. We attended a beginner sushi class booked at the last minute and Ayuko agreed to organise an extra class out of the regular slots (lesson learned: book early!). Complex looking maki sushi become suddenly very easy once you go for it. Not just food and practice but also a lot of very helpful tips and more about history and tradition. Bring your empty stomach and camera. Ayuoko was an excellent teacher with perfect English. Fantastic experience.

Well worth it!. I am an expat living in Tokyo and am always looking for fun, new experiences within the city. When my sister came for a visit this week from the states, I knew it was the perfect excuse to sign up for Ayuko's sushi class. For people who are familiar with Tokyo, I live in Moto Azabu and it was only a short train ride away. Overall, it was a great experience. I really liked Ayuko's teaching style. She gives you a brief background on the history of sushi, the different kinds of sushi, and then the rest of the class is interactive/hands on. We made a total of 7 different kinds of nigiri and one decorative roll. The best part is eating it at the end, however, you almost don't want to after all the hard work that was put into the presentation. When I showed my friends and family a photo of our creation, they couldn't believe that we had made such a beautiful plate of sushi. I look forward to re-creating this recipe for friends and family at home. The class size was small which gave it an intimate feel. We were in class with people from 5 different nationalities (Holland, Norway, Germany, Australia, and Japanese) which made for a pretty incredible experience. I could go on and on, but I highly recommend this class for anyone living in or visiting Tokyo.

Excellent class!. Went to the fish cutting/sushi 4 hour class - overall an excellent experience. There were 4 in the class and we learned about Japanese knives, fish cutting styles, rice prep, nigiri, and fancy maki sushi. Output was excellent (see photo!). Teacher was excellent - perfect english and just the right level of hands-on teaching vs. demonstrating. Recommended for a nice day when you have some time off.

Experience to get to dive into great cooking tradition. Just back from Japan with my wife! Great pleasure and experience to participate in the performance of Ayuko. Beside some tips to lear about history, tradition, technique and standards of how sushi should look like, this was a rare opportunity to penetrate behind glassy cover of Japan for tourist. Tons technology and heritage and work are behind, leaving place for joy and socializing! That's small true about Japan we have managed to get thanks to Buddha Bellies Cooking School!

Sushi. We took the fish cutting/sushi class & found it a fun & informative afternoon.Cutting the fish from scratch was a good experience & something I'll try to do at home.Ayuko was very friendly & well prepared.Some of the pieces of fish had already been cut, but I would've enjoyed slicing these too (from a larger piece) just to practice presentation. Definitely recommend their classes for a fun, hands on experience in Tokyo.

Great sushi class. We were a group of 6 - five in our 60s and my 22 year old son. We were all made to feel very welcome and comfortable. It was a great lesson that started with some of the history behind sushi and techniques used by great sushi chefs. Than we got to make our own sushi under expert guidance. Even the three blokes in our group did well and enjoyed the experience. Highly recommended.

Nice and informative. I took the traditional Japanese course, and was looking to meet other travellers, however when I got there I found out it is a private lesson (which made me a little disappointed). Overall, the cooking experience was nice and informative, make sure you have company when subscribing.

Wonderful Hospitality & Variable Experience. I joined the cooking class of Sushi Rolls. Thanks to the great guidance of the teacher, it is really fun, relaxing and very nice tastes! There were many people who were not good at cooking, but it was no problem and the taste was much nicer than local so-so Sushi restaurant?!

Fun, delicious and memorable experience. It was so much fun to make sushi with Ayuko-san. Besides the fun and informative lesson and delicious and gorgeous sushi lunch we made ourselves, I really enjoyed the interactive time with Ayuko-san who is a native of Tokyo and fluent in English.

Wow! What a day .. Fantastic!. Our family of 4, 2adults and 2 children aged 8 and 13 took part in the decorative sushi making class today and I rate it as a 5 star experience! Our gorgeous host promptly collected us from the metro station as promised and welcomed us into her lovely cooking school. Things were well prepared and organized and Ayukosan was a very warm and professional and spoke English. We made the cutest looking panda sushi and ate it for lunch! The class started with a really interesting history of sushi. I would highly recommend this class to anyone visiting Tokyo.

Great class. I attended Ayukosan's sushi-making class with my mother in July 2014. From start to finish, this class was absorbing, enjoyable, and informative -- not to mention delicious. Ayuko was highly organized and kept us busy the entire time we were there. I definitely recommend this class to anyone who is seeking a fun way to learn more about Japanese cuisine while visiting Tokyo.

Great Teacher and Class. I really enjoyed our sushi making class with Ayuko. She gave us the history of sushi, as well as, special technics for sushi making. My boyfriend and I had a wonderful time!!! The sushi was excellent and we made it!!!!

Great cooking class with a surprise visit from Fuji TV!. My brother and I took the class where we made a main (pork or salmon), 2 side dishes (rolled egg and sesame beans), miso soup from scratch and flavoured rice. Ayuko is a fantastic teacher and explains everything so well! We had a visit from Fuji TV where we were filmed for a Tv show to be aired in September - can't wait! Of course, the most exciting thing that everyone looks forward to is eating your own food you cooked at the very end. A simple way of cooking, and I will definitely be cooking this back at home. Definitely recommend taking a class with Ayuko!

Fun, relaxing and delicious experience!. I took the sushi making class earlier this week and it was a lot of fun. I've made sushi before and have lived in Japan for two years, but still learned some new things. The instructor speaks perfect English, but even if you don't speak English or Japanese, I think you could still enjoy this class because it was easy to follow. Also the location was easy to find!

Fantastic Experience. Attended a sushi making class with my husband and two teenage boys (18 and 15). It was one of the highlights of our trip. You do not have to be a gourmet cook to enjoy this authentic experience. Instructor was gracious and provided clear instruction. Opportunity to purchase cooking books if you desire. Loved making it and eating it!

Wonderful experience!. This was the second time I took a lesson with Buddha Bellies Cooking School. I brought along 3 colleagues, including 1 Muslim and 1 Indian who is a vegetarian from the overseas offices. We did the Washoku (Japanese set meal) lesson. Akiyama san was able to cater to all our dietary restrictions by designing a tofu teriyaki set for my vegetarian colleague, and the chicken teriyaki set for the rest of us. Care was also taken to make sure the dashi (base soup) is vegetarian, and there is no pork element in the meals. She shared many helpful cooking and preparation tips. My colleagues enjoyed themselves thoroughly, which had contributed to their enjoyable experience in Japan.

again a wonderful experience!. Ayuko is a great teacher and in addition to so many details we learned we met wonderful people and ate our food with pleasure. I was so glad to be back after one year for the Udon noodles course - used the perfect sushi rice recipe we received many many times during this year. Compared to other classes and all the prep work needed the 70 $ are well worth spent !! took many classes before around the world but these were the most fun ones because of our teacher's great knowledge not only about cooking but also culture and personality. That's a jour fixe for the next trip!

Great fun!. Really fun course where we made Udon noodles and chicken teriyaki. Ayuko was great at explaining things and we've made both chicken teriyaki and noodles several times since our return to Norway! She also gave me tips on where to buy kitchen knives, which I really appreciated. I can absolutely recommend going here if you're staying in Tokyo a couple of days!

Enjoyable, informative, delicious. I did the sushi making class with my two teenage children and we all thoroughly enjoyed the session with Ayuko. There were four others in the group. It cost about $70 and was well worth it for what we learned, and ate, with optional sake or beer. Ayuko is knowledgable and experienced and guided us through all the steps to make the different kinds of sushi. She has a fantastic collection of books on sushi and all things Japanese, and the atmosphere was friendly and relaxed. I highly recommend this activity and would love to go back for another class.

Really fun experience with solid information. My husband and I took the sushi and sake tasting class last month. It was a lot of fun and very informative for both of us even though we have a wide difference in cooking experience level. Ayuko-san was able to provide a lot of solid information on the details of perfecting one's sushi preparation at home. I plan to take more of her classes every time I return to Tokyo.

Teriyaki Odon Tofu. Attended to the course Tofu Teriyaki Odon workshop. We made our own udon noodles and it shows that the teacher is very experienced in cooking and has good knowledge of what is vegan and what is not.

Fun. I was traveling by myself and this was a perfect addition to my trip. I learned about different kinds of sushi, marveled at what I could make. Ayuko was a lovely host. Kind and knowledgeable. The private library in which it was held was perfect.

Fun, Hands-on, and Educational. I never imagined that preparing nigiri sushi was so interesting! My husband and I took the sushi class and made 7 pieces of nigiri and one maki roll each. The price was about $70 each, and well worth it. There was about 2.5 hours of hands-on cooking, with short explanations and demonstrations preceding each step. There were 5 other people in the class, and we had a great time talking about our stay in Tokyo while working and eating. We ate our sushi at the end of the class, and were served small glasses of sake and a traditional Japanese cake with our meal. Delicious!

Recommended activity in Tokyo. We travelled with teen-agers. One likes museums and sights - one does absolutely not like that kind of activities. One loves shopping, the other one not.. Does this sound familiar? Try taking a cooking course! We all loved it. And the result was astonishing - will do more sushi making at home! Cooking sushi for a person with allergies of fish and seafood in general was not a problem at the course either. We had of course informed about this beforehand. Ayukos instructions were very easy to follow and gave us inspiration to try this at home.

Brilliant. Our guide Miri met us promptly at Jimbacho Metro Station at 11:00 and we soon started our chicken teriyaki and udon class. My family of four were the only participants that day so we got our own private lesson. Miri was brilliant and the class was so much fun. She was patient and easily explained how to make this great food. Eating our creations was awesome and it tasted delicious. We would do another class like this in a heartbeat. She even gave us the recipes to take home with us.

A must do!. I took two of the classes available and I regret not having taken more! Ayuko was an amazing and patient teacher and an adorable host. The classes were fun and very informative. What impressed me the most was how many delicious things we were able to cook in just a couple of hours! I will definitely repeat it next time I'm in Tokyo

Fun!. This was a perfect break from my typical tourist agenda. Ayuko was a knowledgeable, informative, and patient teacher. Smallish group (5) made for a fun, laid back pace. Food was delicious and preparation was interesting. The best things you can bring home from your trip are memories, new appreciations and new skills...Buddha Bellies provides them all. Thank you! Ps..after lunch, a quick walk will bring you to 2k540 Aki-Oka Artisan arcade and all your material souvenir needs can be met in the second half of your afternoon...this has been my favorite day so far!!!

Fun Cooking Class and a Peaceful Oasis in Tokyo. As you walk up two flights of stairs, you leave the noise and crowds of the city behind you and step into a peaceful retreat. I took the sushi making class in this cozy little spot. Ayuko was a great teacher and a gracious host. We had a brief history of sushi, then dove right into to our hands-on class. She made it so easy for us to feel like successful sushi-chefs! Everyone create 8 pieces of nigiri and a beautiful veggie roll.The location is easy to get to - right off the Jimbochu line exit. A great way to spend a couple of hours, learn little about Japanese cuisine, and eat the fruits of your labor!

Sushi Class: a must whilst in Tokyo. Ayu was an excellent teacher and gave me some great insight in the Japenese culture. Lesson was very fun and I am still surprised at being able to produce such great sushi in the space of a few hours. Ayu's knowledge on the history of the sushi is equally as impressive as her enthusiasm and warm welcome. I shall return!

Good Class. Ayuko was a very nice host to us and I did have fun in the class. We cooked a chicken teriyaki and Udon. I have done several other cooking classes, but this one missed on a few points. The first issue with the class was the price. At $70 this is an expensive 2-3 hours to spend with someone, especially when there are six other people in the room with you. I expected more value for the price. I also understand Tokyo is a very expensive city, but with the ingredients we used (chicken, some sauces and flour) I did not feel the money was well spent on ingredients. The second issue with the class is that the hands on portions of the class. Ayuko spent a lot of her time in the kitchen cleaning dishes and preparing the ingredients for the next meal; a task I would have preferred to help with and do (not the cleaning, the prep work for the meals). The final comment is about how we prepared the Udon. This was not an issue, but we could have spent our time learning other things and preparing other dishes. I say this because we spent about 20-25 minutes stepping on the Udon (this is how you prepare large batches so your hands don't become tired). It was a cool thing to do, but one round would have worked or we could have been learning additional things while we were doing this task. There were some positives from the class. The people from the class were very fun, and Ayuko is a great host and person. She was very nice and did a good job explaining dishes as we were making them. Ayuko also taught me a lot about Japanese culture and how some of the customs work. She has a beautiful home and the class is easy to find. She will meet you at the subway and walk you to her class. Ayuko's English is also very good and if you have some questions she will help.Recommendations to make the class better: if the chicken teriyaki and udon is a class I would suggest adding something else to the class to make the class more full of activities. I would also suggest making the recipe book better quality. Some of the classes I have done in the past will give you a book with recipes and descriptions at the end of the book with descriptions of ingredients (pictures sometimes!) so when you go home you can find the ingredients you are cooking with.

Best of the Best!. My partner and I wanted to experience a unique experience while visiting Japan. This was EXACTLY what we were looking for! Personal attention, great quality food and 1st class teaching. If you think you might enjoy a cooking class, you've got to try this one. It was awesome! Insider Tip: We were surprised to learn that the area this experience is located is the best place to find antique books. If you are into books, especially antique ones, you will be shocked to see the number of bookstores in the area.

Still a gem within Tokyo. I wrote one of the initial reviews a few years back when Buddha Bellies was just getting started. Since then, I've taken three additional classes with Ayu. All of them have been wonderful and taught me a variety of Japanese recipes as well as learning about the culture. This most recent visit was trying out their newest offering, washoku, which just received UNESCO Intangible Asset designation. We were treated to a mini-miso tasting, made several traditional Japanese dishes, and taught how to properly plate based on importance of food. The recipes were easy to understand and Ayu provided additional insight to specialized ingredients. She explained the day and then began leading us through each of the dishes. At the end, we were treated to our homemade meal. I can't wait to try these recipes again at home as well as join another class. The only problem is which class to join next!

Amazing class! . I loved every minute of our cooking class with Ayu! My friends and I had such a great time making delicious Japanese food. I learned so much and everything we made was so good! Highly recommend!!

Do it.. I took the udon class with Ayuko and had a great afternoon making noodles in a totally chilled, fun atmosphere with other travellers.The food was excellent - despite the fact that we really did make it ourselves!Also, the location was very easy to get to on the train network, even for jet lagged foreigners like me. My only disappointment was that I didn't get to do the sushi class too!

Ayuko is a brilliant host!. I participated in the decorative sushi class, making cute panda rolls along either 4 other participants. Ayuko was a great teacher and not only explained the process well, but was eager to answer all our questions about Tokyo and Japanese food and culture. I would have loved to complete more of her classes - hopefully next time!

Awesome vegetarian sushi. Being a vegetarian i was very skeptical about learning cooking in Japan, i wasnt sure how it was going to work...however my class at Buddha Bellies was just fantastic!I learnt to make vegetarian sushi and was ecstatic.Ayuko is a very patient and warm teacher, even packed my sushi for me to picnic and gave some free wasabi :)i loved it! cant wait to learn more next time i am in Tokyo

Fun. We took the Sushi-making course offered by Ayuko at the Meishu Centre as we were a group of nine and her school wasn't big enough to accommodate all of us. Firstly I have to say that the centre is NOT easy to find but luckily I had Ayuko's number so we rang her after frantically searching for 15 mins and she came to get us.The course was fun and professional. Ayuko answered questions competently and made us feel welcome. She was patient but not condescending when we made mistakes and we all thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. As a bonus, we also had a Sake tasting which was delicious. I can highly recommend Ayuko and will try more of her courses when I'm back in Tokyo!

Great experience. It was a great introduction to fish cutting and sushi making!Ayuko is a great and very fun teacher. Always ready to explain and very knowledgable. The class was great and I will recommend it to any friends who visit Tokyo.

Learn with a Pro. Great class and a fun relaxed atmosphere. If you want to learn how to make sushi with a professional teacher who will take to through the steps with ease, then this is the class to take. Ayuko’s English is perfect and her teaching style makes you feel like you have been making sushi for years, even if you are a beginner like me. Take this class, but book ahead!May 2014

Highlight of our trip. My girlfriend and I travelled Japan with another couple, and together, we took a bento box cooking class with Ayuko. We so appreciated that she scheduled the class around our arrival time and that the location of the cooking studio was so easy to find. The instructions Ayuko gave us were easy to follow and it was so much fun (and delicious!) to create our own bento boxes. Ayuko was very helpful and even took the time to also answer general questions that we had about Japanese culture and dining. This was a definite highlight of our trip - highly recommended!!

Great Sushi Class. Great introduction class for sushi beginners in Tokyo!Nice group setting.Ayuko - owner and instructor will make sure you learn the basics of sushi making and have fun!Highly recommended.

Great start to the art of sushi making. Excellent atmosphere and surrounding, nice group of participants, great fun, start in sushi making (esp. Nigiri and Maki), personally would have been interested even in some more maki creation (e.g. California Roll, something being easier to perform back home)

Must do Japanese experience!!. A sushi-making class should be on everyone's to do list when visiting Japan, and Buddha Bellies is the perfect experience. I did a sushi class (other classes are available) and it was fantastic fun. Ayuko is a great teacher (English fluent as well) and you are rewarded with a delicious lunch and sake at the end!! Learn the basics (and not so basics) of sushi; we even made a little sushi art.

Everything was awesome. I got there a little late and everyone was already gone. I waited a good 10 minutes or so and finally emailed Ayuko and she came and got me. I think maybe my phone clock is falling behind. Anyways, this class itself is very good! You learn how to make Nigiri as well as a fancier roll. The class is laid out so that once you learn how to make the fancy roll, making more basic rolls makes a lot of sense and you can figure it out on your own. I also was surprised by how difficult making sushi is, some people can make it look so easy. The class itself was very good but...The thing that makes Buddha Bellies really stick out is that Ayuko is a fantastic teacher. I instantly felt welcomed and at ease. Ayuko is extremely friend and she's very good at teaching. Her English is excellent as well. She really makes this course stand out extremely well. It's one of the my favorite things I've done on my trip, and I've been backpacking for 2 months across China, Korea, and Japan. I give her a lot of credit, the class is laid out so it will teach you how to do a lot of things given the time that you're there. My only complaint is that I only took one course for sushi and it's far too late in my vacation to plan another one. The time flew by, I had no idea two hours passed. Ayuko definitely knows what she is doing, and she's friendly and a great teacher. Also, make sure you plan way ahead if you're going to do this class. I started looking as soon as I got into Japan (I was here for about a month) and the only thing I could book was toward the end of my stay. I would strongly suggest booking in advance of your trip or you will be disappointed.

great and tasty experience. we join a Sushi class in Buddha Bellies Cooking School.It was a small group of only 6 persons and we learn to make also Miso soup and few kind of Sushi. Ayuko told us everything we need to know about the food in Japan and it was so interesting. with her help is was really easy to make amazing decorate Sushi.it was our first Sushi making and it was tasty and so much fun!a must do while you are in Tokyo!!!

Amazing. Many thanks to Ayuko for the amazing food and course ran for us. We thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend to all. We were promptly met outside the station and taken up to the cooking room (It is right next to Jimbocho station). After this we learnt how to prep the food and cooked it and it was delicious. Would recommend to all.

Excellent cooking class by Buddha bellies!. I took the fish cutting and sushi making class. I enjoyed both classes. The classes were made simple for a newbie like myself. We made beautiful sushi rolls and delicious sushi!! It made my trip to Tokyo even more enjoyable. I love Tokyo!! Domo arigato :)

A great experience for all the family. As this was our first visit to Japan and we were travelling with our three children (13,11,9), we wanted to learn as much as possible about Japanese culture. Since we all love to eat Japanese food, we decided that a sushi making cookery class would be a great way of learning how to bring some of our experiences home with us! Ayuko-san, who runs the class, was a charming, knowledgable and helpful teacher and made us feel right at home. The whole experience was fantastic from beginning to end!! Her little studio is charming and atmospheric. She is a very good teacher, giving you clear instructions and always happy to lend a helping hand, yet able to step back to let you get on with it, when you just need that bit of extra time to figureit out for yourself. Our children absolutely love sushi and were so proud to have made it themselves! I was impressed that she allowed them to handle massive knives for cutting the sushi. it was so nice to see someone treating children like they can be responsible and competent, instead of 'baby-ing' them. She was also happy to answer our many questions regarding ettiquette and manners. At the end of the class she spent ages pouring over our Tokyo map to point out sights of interest to us and how to get there. Booking and payment from England was really easy and convenient using paypal and Ayuko-san was happy to meet our dietary requirements (halal) without any fuss! She always answered our emails promptly, sometimes within minutes, I can happily say that the class was one of the highlights of our amazing Japan trip and we would highly recommend it to anyone as it is a fun way of learning new skills and learning about Japanese culture from a Japanese person, whose English is excellent. if we ever come back to Tokyo, we will definitely look you up again!!! Thank you for an amazing time!!!

A wonderful experience. From my first contact with Buddha Bellies Cooking school, I felt nothing more than professionalism. From my initial enquiry, through to paying, and then meeting my teacher Ayuko on the day, I couldn't have wished for anything more. I did the fish cutting class which was wonderful - especially considering I was the only student. Ayuko is a wealth of knowledge, and her passion for what she does is wonderful. Once my fish cutting class was finished, other students joined us for a sushi and sashimi making class, which was just as enjoyable. We were made to feel extremely welcomed, and even once the class had finished - the contact with Ayuko had not - as a group photo was emailed to us all! I would highly recommend this cooking class to anyone and everyone who visits Tokyo - regardless of your sex or age!

A very fun and informative afternoon. We decided to do the class after seeing the good reviews on here. It was a very small class, just myself, my boyfriend and another guy which meant that everything we did was overseen by Ayuko. She also sent us the recipes by email which meant we didn't have to write notes while our hands were covered in fish guts which was very helpful! We learnt a lot and have vowed to make sushi for our friends and families when we get back which I am really looking forward to. Overall a fun way to get something more than just a full tummy to take away!

A real gem for experiencing how to make Japanese food. When we travel we love eating nice food and also taking classes whenever there is a chance. So we looked up the possibility for a sushi class in Tokyo and found out about Buddha Bellies Cooking School.Let me just sum up our experience to avoid a repetition what has been already written by other travellers:The whole experience (from the moment of our first contact via email, to payment, detailed information and directions and then the course itself in a very welcoming, warm and enjoyable atmosphere) was simply superb and outstanding, as the instructor/chef Ayuko is incredibly knowledgable and has a great passion for cooking and teaching. Her English, and instruction, is excellent.We will surely be back for more classes as there is no better way to experience Japan and its foodie culture. The only thing that is left to write is that we highly recommend Buddha Bellies Cooking School!!!

Great class with an awesome teacher. It was a rainy day in Tokyo and just the perfect time for a cooking lesson. We were greeted on the dot of 11:00 am by a young lady with a huge smile - this was Ayuko our instructor. Her prep work for the class was perfect and she was so knowledgeable in her art. She patiently explained and listened and made the class feel at ease. It was like sitting around with an International array of friends and enjoying and learning. Ayuko taught us important techniques and history of Japanese cooking. We highly recommend this class to any and everyone. Guys, don't be hesitant to accompany your partners to this class. You will really regret it if you don't go. You will have a fun time, learn some bonus and valuable stuff and get to eat some good food - the food you cooked and drink some good Beer/Sake. Get a hold of Ayuko and take one or more classes. We plan to do so on our next visit in the near future.

Learn about sushi and then how to make it!. Everything about our experience with Buddha Bellies and it's owner, Ayuko, was great. I contacted Ayuko with my dates and she got back to me immediately with class availability. Payment for the class from the US was easy via PayPal. Ayuko sent us very detailed directions for which subway to take, stop to get off and exit to use for the meeting point. We were greeted warmly by Ayuko walked to her school, steps away from the train station. My husband and I took the Sushi class, along with 3 fellow travelers and food enthusiasts. While the rice finished cooking Ayuko shared some of the traditions of the tea ceremony with us, as we made our own cup of tea. Once the rice was ready our sushi lesson began, history and how to...a perfect blend. Ayuko has a wealth of knowledge and is a patient teacher. The quality of the fish we used in our sushi was fresh and wonderful. After we were done with our lesson...we of course got to eat what we made...with Sake, Japanese style, which Ayuko helped us enjoy!Great experience, I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to have a hands on taste of Tokyo.

Brilliant class and a life-long souvineer. We did the bento box cooking class because we'd read the great reviews here and we loved it! We were very excited to learn how to make chicken teriyaki and egg roll - and have since bought an egg roll pan (which we're using tonight). Ayuko is a marvelous teacher - she is patient, calm and kind and gave great instruction. The class is an interactive one but easy to accomplish and a lot of fun.Like someone else mentioned the venue is a lovely surprise and keeping the class small meant we could all chat amongst ourselves, laugh and have a great time.We had a bit of trouble finding the A2 exit - my top tip is that it's across the road (at street level) from the A1 exit.Taking a class here really is the ultimate souvineer of your trip if you love Japanese food. All recipes are provided.

Tokyo In A Mouthful. On our recent trip to Japan we stayed in Tokyo from 26 December 2013 to 3 January 2013, my husband, my sister and myself. We found booking many activities over the Christmas and New Years period in Japan to be a difficult task, many activities, museums and other attractions close down for a well earned break, I started to worry that we should have picked a different time of the year to travel! However, what we did find was a series of activities and attractions that you might call "off the beaten track" in so far as we found all the hidden gems!We are all crazy about Japanese food and cooking in general, so we started the hunt for a good cooking class in the Tokyo area. From our first email to our final goodbye and beyond, Buddha Bellies was an experience not to be missed. We chose to do the bento class so we could try our hands at a variety of dishes. Our host, Ayuko, was just a delight. Ayuko is a natural instructor, who gave us a great appreciation for what we were preparing and explained the cultural relevance of different ingredients and taught us how to prepare a number of dishes that, without hands-on instruction, seem an impossible feat (think tamagoyaki). We attended the class the morning after we arrived in Japan and it was a wonderful introduction to Japanese culture, food and lifestyle. Our group of three was complemented by another lovely tourist and by the end of the class we were all chatting and laughing like old friends. Ayuko provides a comfortable and relaxed environment, while at the same time her excellent communication skills made us all feel like we had taken away a great deal from the class.Accessing the venue was very straightforward but I don't want to divulge much more about the venue and atmosphere, we knew nothing before we arrived and it was such a lovely surprise when we got there that I would hate to spoil it for anyone else!The fee was exceptionally reasonable, we all agreed that the price of the class was insignificant when compared to the value we received.I would recommend this class to families, couples, friends and individuals- so anyone really!

Great experience. I love to cook and learn new cooking techniques so before we left for our trip to Tokyo I looked for Japanese cooking lessons in Tokyo. Through an online search I was able to find Buddha Bellies and read all of the good reviews on Trip Advisor. My husband and I decided on the sushi making class and I e-mailed the instructor to coordinate a day. We were able to make reservations and pay through pay pal. She confirmed the reservation and gave us instructions on where and when to meet her.We were staying near Tokyo station so took the subway to the meeting point at Jimbocho station (there was no Japan Rail stop near by for those with JR Passes). We got there kind of early to be safe and there wasn't too much near by but the instructor, Ayuko, showed up at the meeting point a little early and everyone was already there. The class is done in a very casual atmosphere in I guess a studio right next to the train station. There were 5 others with us (3 folks from Australia, 2 from the UK). We got to make both fancy rolls and nigiri sushi. Ayuko spoke perfect English and gave us all of the tools to make sushi, showing us step by step what to do. The fish quality was great and the sushi was delicious. She also gave us green tea in the beginning and then saki or beer when we ate. All-in-all the experience was great and I loved doing it. She answered all of our questions and both my husband and I had a ton of fun.

Fun Times. Fun addition to visit to Japan and a memorable lesson to take home. In addition to the techniques learned, great education about sushi. Great chance for cultural exchange and a great home made sushi meal.

One of the highlights of our trip. My daughter and I did the Bento Box cooking class and loved it! Ayuko was a great teacher with a pleasant, relaxed style. We enjoyed meeting other people from different parts of the world and the small group made it very personal.I will not forget how to make an egg roll and I will use my Bento skills to make more interesting lunch box items!Ayuko taught us about Japanese cuisine and we all enjoyed eating our creations at the end of the lesson. After the two hour lesson, we travelled with the other class participants to Kappabashi to buy some cooking utensils.

Enjoyable Personalized Experience!. I had the enjoyable experience to make decorative sushi in a small group setting with 2 friends. The 2-hour lesson was conducted entirely in English. Ayuko's lesson was well prepared and conveyed in a very relaxed, friendly and personal manner. Making separate parts and putting the parts together to transform them magically into Panda and Cars shape maki sushis was a very satisfying experience, even though I have never made sushi before. I am definitely looking forward for future lessons!

A highlight of our trip!. We had an amazing morning with Ayuko on our recent trip to Tokyo doing the fish cutting and sushi making class. Ayuko explained everything so well and we were amazed at how with her instruction we were able to prepare sashimi and sushi with ease. I would definitely recommend this class to anyone. Fish cutting involved preparing a fish from the whole fish down to pieces of sashimi. Ayuko was a great teacher and went above and beyond even helping us book a restaurant for that evening that we otherwise would not have been able to do (not being able to speak Japanese). she also advised us of the best place to buy knives which resulted in many purchases. Thank you so much Ayuko for a memorable experience. We're looking forward to trying out our new skills at home!

Great experience in Tokyo!. We took the Bento class at Buddha Bellies on our last day in Tokyo.Ayuko, the owner was absolutely charming and for two hours we learnt how to make Chicken Teriaki , Japanese pickles and Tamago, while learning a lot about Japanese food and culture.The cooking class takes place in a cozy and intimate place (we were two couples) around a nice table amongst packed shelves with hundreds of Japanese cooking books.Atmosphere was great and the bento boxes we created turned out to be lovely and delicious! Thank you Ayuku, we had great fun and would definitely come again next time in Tokyo.

Hands on Authentic Japanese Washoku cooking. We had a wonderful Washoku cooking lesson with Ayuko. She taught us how to make Dashi from scratch, and she took care to explain clearly each and every step, and also explained how the Washoku set is arranged. There was no rush and the class was conducted in a casual atmosphere. Very informative and i highly recommended this.

The bento box class. Ayuko is an excellent teacher and made the concept of the Japanese bento box very clear to me, as well as having prepared documentation and the ingredients well in advance. I loved being with her, and the reward of having the pleasure of eating what we made, was real! A great experience!

A deep & amazing insight of the Japanese Culture. The sushi class with Ayuko is a really great experience I strongly recommend!Ayuko speaks perfectly english, is really nice and takes really good care of her "students".Location is easy to find, 1 min away from Jimbocho station. Excellent atmosphere and the place is very clean & quite. Adding to that, the sushis we prepared were delicisous, and the sake even more.Enjoy!!!

Sincerely my favorite experience in Tokyo. Ayuko is a wonderful teacher and does a great job showing you how to make sushi. She was easily able to accommodate my vegetarian diet, and had creative delicious vegetarian recipes for what I could make. The space was very homey and easy to find. I would highly recommend Ayuko's class to any friends travelling to Japan!

Excellent. It was an excellent experience of learning how to make sushi in Japan! You are cooking in cosy friendly-style atmosphere, like on a kitchen of one of your friends! The master is very helpful, and explains everything in detail. During this sushi class we have made not only nigiris, but also decorated sophisticated rolls! It was awesome)) After sushi, we were also shown how to make macha! And everything is discussed, and done in so friendly manner! So cosy! So Easy)) It was an awesome japanese experience! I have also recommended it to all of my friends, who are visiting Japan. 3 of them have already visited this course, and were more than satisfied with course!

Great cooking class!. This was an overall great experience. I took my mom to Ayuko's bento box class as part of her Christmas present. She loved it!!! Very intimate cooking class in a private library. There are no real kitchen facilities, just hot burners, but that did not take away for the positive experience. Ayuko is super nice and speaks great English. The class includes recipes, sake or beer, desert, and tea! As an expat living in Japan I will definitely bring future guests to Ayuko's class!

Inspiring!. I went to couple of Buddha Bellies Cooking classes - since the first ever class. Ayuko gives clear and step-by-step instructions in English on how to make Japanese food at home. Her warm and patient character makes the class personal and fun. The venue is cozy where you can relax with a friend or two. I highly recommend anyone to experience Japan through your bellies and return to your home country with extra knowledge on home cooking. My favourite classes were Teriyaki chicken and udon class. !
Excellent ! . Ayuko-San was amazing. Highly recommended stop for any tourist. I learned a lot and loved the experience. It's small, quaint, and personal. Don't think twice about it!

One of the best experiences in Tokyo...great for singles couples or the whole family. My husband, our cousin and I did the Buddha Bellies Cooking School including fish cutting last weekend and it was one of the most fun things we did in Tokyo. The instructor is amazing with great english. It is a great mix of instruction and fun and she is patient. Fish cutting is great as she teaches you the proper way how to fillet a fish in Tokyo that we later ate as Sashimi. Also, making your own sushi and then enjoying it is very rewarding. I would highly recommend it for families, singles, couples or as a business event for a small group.

Great Way To Do Something Different. We spent a week in Tokyo, and met Ayuko on our third day there, for her sushi class. This was such a nice reprieve from the sights and tourist attractions of Tokyo. We spent a couple hours learning the process (and becoming aware of the difficulty) of properly fileting a fish and preparing it into sushi, as well as learning how to make nigiri and a sushi roll. The ambiance was excellent, Ayuko was incredibly friendly and kind, and the entire experience was highly enjoyable. It certainly gave us a new appreciation for what goes into making sushi! Do yourself a favor and sign up for this class when you're in Tokyo!

Learning Gyosa, Sushi, Maki and Oyako-Don. It was a great experience for my wife and me to learn all those good japanese dishes in private class from Ayuko-san who received us with lots of kindness, patience and good humour. We are now ready to receive our friends with tasty japanse food at home in Switzerland. Thanks again, we love Japan!Niki Michel

Fantastic sushi learning!. I took Ayuko's sushi class for the first time and found it very very satisfying.Although I am a Japanese, I never had a chance to learn how to make sushi till I joined this cooking class.It was very intimate atmosphere with international guests but her lecture was very professional and detailed.After taking this class, I had a sushi party at home with recipe that I learned here and all of my friends were so happy with my sushi!!

The class was an amazing experience.. The class was an amazing experience.
Ayuko is very knowledgeable.
I was surprised because after the demonstration, they prepared a variety of appetizers and Japanese wine that were simply delicious!
I highly recommend this class and will be back for more!

Great hands-on experience. I thoroughly enjoyed my vegetarian sushi class. I was very lucky to have Ayuko to myself, and she was very easy to chat to. The types of sushi we made were varied, and easy enough for beginners to make, while still looking really impressive when finished. Everything was yummy, and I feel confident that I can re-make it all at home with the aid of Ayuko's take home instructions. I was really worried about getting lost and not finding the class, but it was very easy to get to Jimbocho station, and the class is right next door to the station. There was lots to see nearby after the class, and Ayuko was very helpful in giving me directions around the area. This was one of the best things I did in Japan. I am particularly grateful that they offer a vegetarian class, as vegetarian food is not common in Japan.

Excellent experience!!. I had the fortune to be the only one in the class. So practically it was personalized. Ayuko is really friendly and nice. She speaks very good English and tells you everything about how to make a really good sushi. I completely recommend it!
So cool!. I had the fortune to be the only one in the class, so it was a personalized class. You learn good things and tricks of how to make real japanese sushi and Ayuko is very kind. Recommended!

Sushi course in a fantastic little place.. Me and my son had a great time. He is 10 and it was a great experience cutting the fish and do sushi and sashimi together. Easy to find this place. Fantastic english speaking Japanese woman.

Fun way to try sushi. This was a great way to learn how to make traditional Japanese food from the world's capital of sushi! Ayuko (our teacher) was lovely and her English was perfect - as well as a qualified chef she is also an English teacher. We made nori roles and impressive square sushi (*very* fancy) using fresh fish from Tsukiji market. It was all delicious, and I'm not usually a fan of seafood. We also made traditional matcha green tea and sampled top-quality sake. I had a great time and the whole experience was friendly and informative. I would definitely recommend the Buddha Bellies class for anyone looking for something a little different during their stay in Tokyo, as well as an opportunity to try delicious, fresh sushi - made by you.

A different way to experience Japan. A fun way to spend a couple of hours in a different country. Ayuko has a good command of English and runs a well-oiled operation. From the first email enquiry, you will receive a request to pay via PayPal for upfront payment. Once that is sorted, you are locked in and sent instructions on where to meet. Clear directions are given and 11am on the dot, Ayuko arrives to bring us to the studio for the class and it's the building right next to the station – very convenient. The class is held in a beautiful boutique library with a very nice pleasant set up. Thoroughly enjoyable and lots of laughs.

More than just a cooking class!. Ayuko - our teacher - is wonderful. She is an English teacher and is also training in traditional Japanese cooking. The night was full of learning how to make sushi rice, nori rolls and to make traditional tea. A more complicated technique than I had thought but doable, delicious and can't wait to try at home. Ended up making a huge meal. Learning about Ayuko's life and outlook on life was fascinating and hearing new tips from other travellers about new places to try in Japan was also great. Brilliant night!

Wonderful class. Hi AyukoThank you so much for a wonderful evening last nightWe thoroughly enjoyed our sushi making class and are excited to try our skills back homeYou made us feel very welcome and shared your knowledge and insight into Japanese culture as well as cuisine.It was a real highlight of our tripLeora and Ric

Wonderful Experience. We had so much fun. Ayuko customized our class by having us meet her early to learn how to make miso soup and tamago. We also asked to have only the vegetable sushi so that we can make it at home without worrying about raw fish. After teaching us tamago and miso, other guests joined us to learn how to make sushi. Ayuko was lovely and we can now make our own sushi at home.

hi ayuko!. as part of my recent visit to Tokyo I attended a couple of classes with Buddha bellies. I have been a professional cook for many years and wanted some first hand knowledge and experience with Japanese food. our host and instructor ayuko was a pleasure to spend time with and conducted her class in a very relaxed yet informative way. we had a lot of fun and learned much cooking our own dinner using simple age - old Japanese cooking techniques. a great experience!! next time I go back to Tokyo I will book in for a whole week. highly recommended. g

Fun and personal. The workshop is a great mixture of having a good time and learning the basics of making sushi. As you can see in the pictures there is only room for a small group of people, making the workshop very warm and personal and allows to easily connect with other participants.

Now that was fun!. What a wonderful experience! But more importantly having such a kind instructor like Ayuko teaching you how to make sushi. Her knowledge and passion for Japanese cuisine and culture leaves you inspired. The class was a lot of fun and a must if your in Tokyo.

loved the veggie sushi class!. My husband and I just loved the veggie sushi class. Ayuko is such a kind and wonderful instructor. The group size was nice and small, and we just loved learning more about Japanese food. Definitely one of our favorite days spent in Tokyo.

Memorable and highly recommended sushi making experience. This sushi making class was recommended to us by our local Japanese friend. We are so glad she did, as it was definitely one of the highlights of our trip.This class would suit anyone interested in learning to make sushi, whether you are a complete novice or have plenty of cooking experience, regardless of age. Before the class even began, Ms. Akiyama was kind enough to meet us at the nearby station to make sure we didn't get lost.The class was itself was conducted in a very relaxed environment and was fantastic value for money. Not only did we get to eat our creations (made with an assortment of fresh seafood and served with beer or sake as lunch at the end of the class), but there were also little bonuses (such as tea and sweets) that made it even better value. Our host was really friendly and knowledgable, and so in between being shown sushi making techniques there was also plenty of interesting discussion regarding the art of making sushi, as well as various restaurants around Tokyo.As well as the sushi class there are also other classes available, and so if we are ever back in Tokyo we'd definitely seek this experience out again.

Sushi In Jimbocho. Yummy, friendly and great for older kids. We had a great time with Ayuko, a very warm, patient and friendly host who taught us the basics of sushi making and helped us turn out a very impressive sushi plate.In a small, warmly-lit room (bookshop by day), our group - including my 10 and 12 year old boys - turned our hands to 2 types of sushi and the 2 hours just flew by. We enjoyed our own creations and each other's company with a glass of beer, sake or green tea.On a practical level, Buddha Bellies is a super-easy commute along several subway lines and the school is right next door to Jimbocho Station.

Very nice intro to sushi. I took this class on my last visit to Tokyo, which was a very fast paced trip. It was lovely being in Ayuko's quiet space and focusing on sushi. I am a fairly advanced home cook but I definitely learned a few tricks that I didn't know and would have been difficult to pick up from a book. I won't say what they are because you should take the class if you are interested!

Awesome cooking experience. Fabulous day with a fabulous host. This is what Japan is all about to me its food. This course was a great way to learn the basics of Japanese cooking and it was a very well organized day. The best thing is you get to sit down after and eat what the class has prepared. Its also a great way to meet other people.

Port in a storm. We had a great couple of hours here. Apparently a pretty severe typhoon passed through Tokyo during our class and we didn't even not ce it. I'm not even a sushi fan particularly but I thoroughly enjoyed making it and the sashimi and the expert guidance of Ayuko. Before this, I would never have expected to be able to make something that looked and tasted like the real thing. I also loved the semi-library location with its fascinating collection of books. Warmly recommended.

Fun activity in Tokyo!. I had a great time learning not only how to make sushi, but also learning about the specific points of Japanese cooking. Ayuko taught us how to handle Japanese rice, the correct weight of the rice ball for nigiri, and the correct way to position the chopsticks on the table. She is a great teacher and I had a lot of fun!The only thing I would suggest is going step-by-step through the roll making instead of demonstrating the whole thing at once. It took some time for me to recall each step individually. But excellent teaching throughout!

Tricks of the sushi trade. Apparently it takes 10 years to become a sushi chef.
